content:
ry 27, 2014
												Divinty 2 managed to keep me interested in its gameplay for at least 10 hours, which can be rare in single player games.  During that 10 hours, I found my self very interested, however the only thing I felt was lacking was the Combat system.  It felt too simple for me; and while its been quite some time between writing this review and playing it; I still felt like it was overall a good game.  I did not stick through till the end of this game, mainly because it started feeling like an MMO.  I was just running around doing the same things over and over again, and that was all I could look forward to doing in the future of the game.  Still, I recommend this game, as I know that there are many gamers out there who enjoy this; and I did find some enjoyment within it.  It was certainly worth the low price I had paid for it, as it was on sale at the time.

content:
er 19, 2016
												Let me get a couple things out of the way. First, I don't consider this to be a "bad" game in spite of the glaring red mark, but I can't really see myself recommending it to anyone either. Second there are some pretty terrible graphics issues right out of the gate, and if you do decide to pick it up I strongly encourage you to check out the pcgaming wiki page for it, as well as updating all relevant software. I admit that I haven't finished the game at this point, but I've also lost any interest in continuing.The combat in Divinity 2 is pretty comparable to something like World of Warcraft, you get a skillbar and a number of passive(dull minor % buffs) and active skills. The skills you can learn are limited by only your character level, which is pretty cool as it allows you to be open and creative with how you build your character, avoid the various crap skills, etc. When actually putting them into practice though, I found that it was the usual tedious rinse repeat of skill rotations, and for the most part enemies were easily avoided, especially early on. After a few hours in the game you'll run into quite a large number of enemies whose attacks cannot be avoided though: spell casters with instant hit point blasts, archers whose normal attacks can usually be avoided but whose special skills curve through the air magically tracking you. In fact a couple of the more annoying boss battles I experienced were against archers who had an undodgable stun (something like four seconds!), that they followed up with an explosive shot and various other attacks. The first of these encounters I had to cheese by exploiting line of sight, the second one I eventually realized could be blinded, and I wound up reloading until I got a successful blind before being stunned and gibbed. Ugh, and enemy healers, just annoying. Or maybe I'm just a bit jealous because when I got out of tougher fights in the earlier portions of the game I had to prance about looking for something else to do while waiting for my Hitpoints and Mana to ever so slowly crawl back up. Thankfully they seem to recover when you're in dialogs and inventory screens.The autosave function is a joke. In my playthrough I could count on it triggering maybe once every 3 hours. It's a bit painful to discover that after coming from more modern titles, but then the quicksave instinct quickly returns...and allows for any imaginable amount of save scumming you are comfortable with. Spend XP to mindread someone then reload? Sure, why not? I actually made an effort not to do this, but it still feels like a design oversight.Ah, but you do get to turn into a dragon...after several hours carving through the first few areas of the game. It is great at first...buuuut it got old pretty quick for me. Dragon gameplay is completely segregated from human gameplay, which admittedly is kinda necessary to keep the human side relevant without putting in something like a "dragon gauge" or whatever. Still, it's kinda silly to not even be able to see enemies on the ground while you're in dragon mode. In one instance I was flying around inside a giant cavern disabling barriers to get at a necromancer, when I dropped the last one I was expecting to be able deliver a big ol' dragon ♥♥♥♥♥smack, but no one was there. I transform to human and land and the necromancer is there ready to take me on. Great. Transform back into dragon, he runs off and disappears into the aether. Very disappointing. At first playing as the dragon felt empowering and kind of awesome, but then it quickly felt very easy and also inconsequential, because nothing I did as a dragon was going to make my human life much better.The writing kinda reminds me of various bioware games as far as the overall plot goes, but without much of the binary  meter driven morality. Most of the dialog options didn't seem to matter all that much though, and seemed to amount to a binary I am or am not being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ here. NPCs are eh, believable if not charming, fully voiced except for the main character which is impressive. Their animations seem pretty spastic at times for my taste, but it's pretty good still. No NPC party members outside of some short quest related instances, at least for the duration of my playthrough. I feel like that would've made a large difference in my impression of the game too, so more's the pity.The game holds up fairly well visually and has some amusing if simple puzzles, and clever tricks here and there. There is definitely some respectable take away if you can stand the lackluster combat and mechanics, being trapped in a room after quicksaving, etc.

content:
y 26, 2015
												This is a womderful game. The quests themselfs are the highlight, most are excellent, well above the norm, with witty writing and interesting choices. The open level design as well allows the player freedom to explore. Now only on level ground but elevated surfaces making the enviorments feel diffrent from other fantasy games. The main weak point is the combat: it's highly imbalanced. The start of th e game is difficult: with enemies able to one hit kill the player on higher difficulties, howver, as the game progresses, they begin to barely dent you. leveling up feels pointless, even on nightmare. It also includes the expansion pack "Flames Of Vengence" that is equally high in quility with excellent quests and hours of content. A solid RPG, recommended for those who like to think when it comes to quests and exploring enviroments.

content:
r 31, 2016
												This game has some of the most hilarious writing I've seen in a video game since I played the original fallouts and nwn games.  While I feel the combat is very lacking (the game makes up for it by letting you turn INTO A DRAGON), the game more than makes up for it in the story telling.  Well, in most cases.  I've always felt that the background lore to the divinity series is largely nonsensical and at times moronic, but the quests, dialogue and character interaction have always been top notch.  This is probably their best game in that regard.The expansion really solidifies that, with the new person stuck in your head being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wizard instead of a certain mumble mumble spoilers.  Whoever did the voice acting for this guy nailed it, and whoever wrote the character deserves an award.  Alternatively the 'good' wizard is a raving lunatic whos irritating insanity meant I could never side with him.If you make the right choices, you get a certain bonus boss at the end of the game who chides the actual boss for being stupid and not getting you on their side.  It was possibly the funniest thing in the entire game.  Great writing, good graphics, meh combat, and satisfying soundtrack.   Worth a purchase.

content:
21, 2016
												This game is awesome. I picked it up and Beyond Divinity and Divine Divinity for five dollars during a steam sale. Best five dollars I've ever spent (although honestly, I would pay the regular $20 price tag.) I keep expecting the game to end but after 31 hours (with 95% of the sidequests finished) I realize I have only now hit the half-way point. Which is awesome. Lots of games end by the time you're powerful enough. A lot of reviews complain that the levelling doesn't make sense or the controls are awkward. If you've played Divinity: Original Sin and enjoyed it, then you'll probably enjoy this game. The writing or story isn't as good as in Original Sin but its still decent. The levelling is complicated in that if you don't want to start over a few times until you find a good build you should just look up a character guide. I spent 20 hours in Original Sin finding a good character set up, so I just went straight to a character guide. As far as the combat, its not the most polished, but its functional, works well, and is enjoyable.The best part of the game is where you get to turn into a mother ♥♥♥♥ing dragon. I didn't even know you could do that when I bought the game. Its awesome. It makes travelling around really fast and if your human character is a little awkward when it comes to fighting, its the complete opposite for the dragon. Everything is smooth and fast and exciting.I'd give it an 8/10. Definitely worth the $20 price from a game length aspect but you can easily pick it up for a lot less since it goes on sale pretty frequently.

content:
y 18, 2014
												English isnt my Native Language so please Excuse my grammar/Spelling mistakesDivinity 2 beeing the 3rd game in the Divinity Series after Divine Divinity ( one of my favourite RPGs of all time) and Beyond Divinity ( cant really say too much about it although my memories about it dont say it was nearly as good as DIvine Divinty), Showing us that counting to 3 is obviously not amongst the talents of Larian Studios....But now for the Review:The Bad:The fist thing in the game you will notice is the Ridicoulus Animations, not really bad, but kinda stupid looking. it goes from really stupid jump animations for female Characters to Roundhouse kicks in Melee combat until you get the 2 handed Weapons.A sommersault for standart frontal moving atack with 2 handen weapons looks REALLLY Stupid and shows that either the creators had no ideas how someone uses a sword or just said " we dont want anyone taking our melee fighters seriously anyways" But that is just the tip of the Iceberg. The Combat can at times be really frustrating due to Enemies Stunlocking the player for large amounts of Time. And Some Balancing Issues that make the game really easy after a while due to a health regeneration that constantly heals more life per second than the best Health potion in the game, (at about 50 health per second at any time) Which i felt i needed to get after getting stunlocked constantly while fighting 10 + enemies at a time  and  thus not beeing able to even  use Health Potions due to stunlock.Ranged Combat got Boring really fast for me since you have next to no influence to your aiming, which does not mean you cannot hit the enemie you want, but skill in aiming doesnt really get rewarded (by extra critical hits on head or something like that), since it kinda auto aims, so i changed to melee heavy Character after about 3 hours of playtime.Another big Issue with the combat is that you cannot possibly know which class your enemie has based of his appearance. you meat enemy healers that charge at you with 2 handSwords as much as you meet them with bow and arrow, or Summoners that dual wield Sword/mace , or 2 hand weapon or bow and arrow. the worst thing happening to me in regardto this was in one of the Flying Fortresses where Enemies with the Skin of Deamons were shown to me as "Wizards"- The sometimes Unclear Difference between Summoner , healer , Soccerer , Wizzard and Ranger Doesnt help Either  as it makes focusing dangerous enemies unecesaryly hard and makes the Combat sometimes Very Annoying, Confusing and Frustrating.Then there is the Story:The Games Story Suffers From some Really inconsistent Quality in Writing, event tough there are a lot of good written quests and characters in the game the overarching main-storyline suffers from many issues, plotholes and flaws. While some Characters From Previous Games return, most importantly the Wizard Zandalor that already Appeared in Divinie Divinity, zandalors main role is to breach the fourth wall, and spouting some things at the player as if it a 6th School Play , And A "Villan", a Term that i use rather loosely, that does appear as if he ist cut straight from a James Bond 007 movie, always appearing in front of the player, just to dump a few henchmen in the room and disappear leaving you to "die" in his Deathtrap, Which you of course escape rather easily, and after the third time he appears you just laugh at him for beeing so incompetent and it becomes impossible to take him seriously due to him beeing about as much of a threat as Team Rocket. the Load Screen advice to Run from him whenever you see him becomes a complete mockery once you finish the game and notice  there is not a single fight against him in the whole game instead they recycle almost all the previous boss mosters at the end of a game to make for a "final boss fight" Many other of my Complaints about Plotholes and mistakes in the Story i wont elaborate in this review to keep it spoiler free.The end comes a bit sudden and is a bit confusing, as the Add-on automatically started i didnt even notice the base-game ended at first.Aditonally:The Game feels really unfinished or rushed at many points, which gets really obvious when you reach Aleroth and Notice that the big City got demoted to a Linear "run in, kill enemies, run out" mission, only to be expanded to its "orignial size" to be explored in the "flames of vengance" addon. also a large part of the world map seems to have been planned out as accessable area, but was never included in the game. In a Developers Vidoe included in the "developers cut" they say that they were restriced by the xbox360s abilitys at the time of development.After so Much Bad i had s to say about the game you may aks: "why does steam tell me you Recommend the game?"The Good : Exploring the World is A LOT of Fun. If it is on foot with a good freedom of movement due to high jumps and only few "invisible walls". Or Soaring through the Skies as a Dragon, Its A lot of Fun Gliding through the beautiful Landscapes in Dragon From or exploring theground on foot. Additonally the world is Filled with great written and funny Characters and encounters throughout the whole world. at every Cornor you find an intresting side quest that motivates you to immerse yourself into the gameworld.where the Main story suffers from many mistakes, the sidequest are made excellent and the real  core of this game. Especially a  travellign summoner named Bellegar always got a chuckle out of me and i really enjoyed the encounters with him or his deeds in the world. As well as the White Killer Rabbit (undoubtably a refernce to Monty Python and the Holy Grail)Also There are Bunch of Riddles mixed in the Gameplay that really enrich the dungeons and gameplayexperience.Also the game has a few neat nods to Divine Divinity that i really enjoyed. for example the talking skeleton that you could kill by making him think about what exaclty holds him together with nearly exactly the same words as a conversation between 2 skeltons in DivineDivinity.Or a magical whishing well that complaints about another magical well that got arrogant after it fulfilled a wish to the hero of Divine Divinity.All those things Made the world feel really alive and even tough the game was Annoing and frustrating at times i just couldnt stop Playing the game (which is a really good thing that not many games manage to do for me), beacause i was too much involved into the Game world. And all in all  i had a great time with the  Game and can really recommend it to others for playingConclusion:A Game with MANY issues, but Enough good Aspects and fun elements to make it Really worth your Time.i can  recommend the game to everyone who likes to dive into a fantastic world and explore every single part and sidequest of it and can turn a blind eye on the issues of the game.I Hope i could give you an insight to my experience of the game and i wish you as much fun with the game as i had :D

content:
4, 2015
												One of the MOST underrated RPGs ever. The game has a very good “RGP” feel, progression/leveling is terrific and gives you a good feel of advancement of character and always keeps you interested in the “next level”.Combat is RPG like but has a slight feel of action-RPG, and this shouldn’t scare you off is you don’t like action RPGs, since it’s done very well, and still feels like you are playing an RPG like say (Dragon Age). To the same point if you like, more “action” in your RPG then you won’t be disappointed either.Different combat systems are fantastic, you can do some mix match as well to go from magic/combat/ranged, it’s done very well, and this gives good strength to the replaybility factor, since you want to experience.If you like real time RPGs and you don’t have this game, what are you waiting for, this is a hidden GEM of a game. •	Loot system is excellent, there is enchantment of weapons/gear as well•	You can morph into a dragon (and level up your dragon mode)•	Has a fully capable console, which allows you to “cheat” or do some other interesting things with the game.•	Story is 8.5/10•	Combat 10/10•	Visuals/Art style 9.5/10 (yes the game is older, but if you ask me it still stands up nicely)•	Replay ability 10/10•	Sound/Music 9/10•	Overall 9/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												Tqake everything you think you know about RPG games,  YOU KNOW THE WAY THEY ARE DESIGNED AND PLAYED,  All the dungeon crawling, leveling up and game play and put them in a bag and toss them into the trash.   Because the way you see and play and invole yoursel with the game will be changed forever.     It starts out with you being a new dragon slayer and going to a place called Farglow to learn the basics of dragon slaying.   You will choose what class you want to be.  There are 3 here to choose from: MAGE,  FIGHTER,and RANGER.  SOME HAVE SAID THAT CHARACTER CHOICE AND CREATION RUN ALONG THE SIMPLE.   I think you will develop your character through the choice of over 30 skills which are devided into the three mentioned clases plus a priest class.   The basic development fall into two basic ways to develop your character.   You can develop a  character using skills from his class or you cat develop one using skill choices from several classes.This will let you develop a character that suits your style.  A single class character will be stronger and a character developed using skill from more than one class  will be more visital,    I started as a fighter but soon saw the advantageto being good with a bow.  Keep in mind that your class choice  will give you some skills to start the game depending on the class.     The skills are devided into 2 types active and passive.  You can have as many passive skills as yo wish,  The active skills and other items are placed in a 8 hotkey display at the bottom of the screen.  You can have more active skill and special abilities but only 8 will be in the hotkeys. The special ability's things you can do,     Each time you gain a level you get 6 stat points  that you can increase one of your 5 ststs.  You also get 1 skill points to purchase a new skill or improve an exsisting skill,   Each skill has 5 levels till later in the game.  Take note with just onepoint/turn you will have to learn the hard way that once you make a choice it can not be changed till later in the game.      Because of the way this game levelup and does not use the game levels are based on your level some interesting things happen.  If you get into a situation where your character is higher that the NPC monsters then you may have a battle where the NPC gets his lickls and you get a small number of xp points or eve 0,  Which  leads to the practice of witholding stat points and even skill points till you come acxross NPC's who give you more xp points.  This may sound strange but in playing the gqame it does work.  I like it because it limits the practice of "Power Leveling" The way the game levels is something you should take at face value like many of the game  mechcanics work in the game if you just usr them and in time it will let you see what a marvolus game this is...It is hard but ther is always a way.   Now the combat will really be frustrating at first.  You do not have nice turn based combat because it is real time.  When you get into the second part of the game in the begining section you will encounter large groups of hostile NPC'sand will have to develop ways to deal with them.   Once an area or a group of units is dead they stay that way.There is the run in ....kill a couple..aned try to get out into a safe place. save and repeat.     Different movement skills are used in the game to solve problems and quests.  Once again this is not the normal thing in many RPG's.   For example  there are many kinds of containers to open and a bright yellow light will occur if  something can be opened including  some empty containers.  Now depending on the angle of you mouse and how your character is this  yellow light may not always show up. Moving you character slowly in each direction will help.  Also a messahe will apear next to the hotkey area and tell you there is something to open or use or take.  One of the more difficult things you will have to learn is jumping.  Many quests have platforms to jump from one to the next and some platfors arte moving,  There is a learning curve if you are using a mouse and keyboard (controlers  are not enabled for the most part   There are many wepons, armor inchantments, charms, and pluses for stats that you will be able to use depending on you level.  There are some who do not like the armor methods used in the game because they can't  get matching sets.  I find no ewason to comment on this because the absurdity is plain to see. It is possible to taloy your character in many different way to reach a certain result.  If you find a situation that call for an archer, maage or whatever then you cause rifferent selections of eqyuipment, to get the job done. I think this is a great game with many vqarid and challanging  problems.   It never fails to have me shaking  my head.  The graphics are just right for the game theyare neither to strong or two week.   One thing that I have never seen in an RPG is the notebook tab.  Her yoyu wil;l find several very useful  features,   Thgere is one that has all of your conversionsso if you are a little confused about speaking to a NPC it is all there every blessed word.  There is one that has every combataction and the result and there is one that has all the NPC's that you have dispached.  The quests are handled in a list of completed quests and open quests you are workinmg on.  A nice feature is the quests that are open are in different colors so you can tell when one is compleated or  can't be compleated or is reasdy to complete.  There are things I may not like but I do not mention them unless they seem out of place.  I write this review to tell the reader how the game works.  There are games I do not like because I can see that they could have done better but did not due to such thingss as cost of development, or are just game put on the market to make money.  I do not play games in development or bata  games bedcause I have better things to do.   I do not comment on other reviews because I believe they are voicing ther opinion which I see has no place in a review.   Expressing you opinion is not the way I think a review should be done.  I could be wrong and people might take this review as being to high and mighty, but it is just the way I see it.

content:
ry 10, 2016
												Well this is something I try not to do often. Usually when I review a game I like to have at least 5+ hours or if it has an end I'd prefer to have made it passed the games story, but I just can't play this anymore. So with my meager 3 hours I'm just goint to put my thoughts down. Also a warning that'll hopefully let you know to take my review with a grain of salt. I'm not a huge fan of most of these rpg games in general, in a broader sense I'm not a fan of games that make you do everything alone. So this game had a strike against it for me right off the bat, because no matter how important they make your quests/missions/whatever sound you're always 100% alone (aside from your temporary summons).Also, I know this is common in games with questing but I'm just saying. If you're trying to make someone feel a part of an epic story, the least epic feeling thing you can do is make them spend loads of time saving pigs from slaughter, or helping some farmers wife leave her husband. They feel more like chores than quests.Pros:Even though it's an older game it's graphics aren't terrible so it's not eye destroying if you're used to todays quality.The story sounded like it could be pretty interesting from what little I got of it.Cons:Animations are ♥♥♥♥♥. Jumps are awkward, attacks are clumsy, and people animate when they talk to you like they're having a siezure.Combat is boring, this was a big one for me. You have to fight your way passed everything and even if you have quite a few skills I couldn't see it being more fun.Difficulty is all over. I was killing things easily that were 1-2 levels under me, taking them on a few at a time, but as soon as I fight 2 things on level even though they were ranged and I dodged most of their attacks I was getting melted. When they did hit me it was dealing loads of damage and I don't know how I could've prevented it. I was done with the quests I could do before the area so leveling was out of the question, and the gear I could've bought was hardly any better than what I had on.Voice acting is mediocre at best, there's some decent dialog but it's mostly bland and the voices were giving me a headache.The undead I could summon were butchered in seconds, the skills I unlocked were apparently the worst I could get (I'm good at choosing like that) since they hardly made a difference and auto attacking was basically all I did.All in all I'd recommend looking for something else, I really wish I'd have played one less hour so I could request a refund for this. I'll never touch it again.

content:
10, 2016
												A friend got me this game as a Steam gift, so I figured I'd try it out! Here're my thoughts on Divinity II:Pros- The dialogue is actually pretty humorous, and it doesn't come off as if it's trying too hard. The guards at the beginning are funny. :P- There's only a moderate level of customization options, BUT you can change your name, appearance, and even your gender and class at any time.- The ability to mindread in exchange for experience adds a cool layer of depth you don't normally see to character interaction.- Pretty good about not being entirely linear. You find yourself wandering around a lot, doing what you want to do, until you run into enemies that are too high for your level. That's really the main metric that makes you stop from venturing into certain areas.- I'M A FRIGGEN DRAGON GUYS DUUUDENeutral- There's a pretty even number of memorable and unmemorable characters you run into.Cons- The game isn't incredibly engaging. It feels like it's missing something, but I can't put my finger on what.- The music is very sub-par and almost unfitting. I find myself pretty much always listening to external music through Spotify or something while playing.- Melee is wayyy harder than being a ranger or mage. That's not too rare in RPGs, but it's pretty much by leagues and leagues here.- The lack of romances makes me sad, just because I love those. Also, everyone reacts to you the exact same, no matter your race or gender.- A lot of the guards' faces look exactly the same.- You frequently get trapped in areas where the level around you is way too high and you have little way of knowing until you're already engaged in a fight. Some say the game is just "hard," but there's a pretty clear difference between needless reloads and a game being truly, properly challenging.So there you have it. Divinity II is fun in its own way, but I can't play for longer than an hour or two at a time, for whatever reason. The game isn't engaging for long periods, I suppose.Atmosphere: 7/10Fun: 6/10Frustration: LowReplay Value: LowControls: IntuitiveRating: 5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2013
												A very underrated game, Divinity II captured my attention a few years ago when Dragon Knight's saga had been released. The combat is relatively simple, yet it feels very sweet, especially near the endgame when you're taking on literal hordes of enemies, cutting them all down with superior damage.While I found the experience very fun, I can't help but mention glaring problems I had with the game, for one, the skill system was clearly geared for only damage dealers, there was nothing that I felt, would've fit a support/tank build, (which is understandable, since this is a SP game), but it got worse as I went forward, realizing how stupidly powerful I was with Dual wielding vs. any other set (especially against Bows, Bows really fell short in the end game). More specifically, the life drain skill was incredibly powerful at later levels, to the point where my high damage, low defense character was clearing rooms and never having to pop a potion or use a heal.Another issue I had was that the game felt clearly rushed, as the environment and characters all felt very shallow, with little of anything that you could actually do, outside of reading everyone's mind or doing missions. With very little characterization of non main plot characters, (with exception to a few), I felt that completing side missions was really just an excuse to get more XP, and since monsters don't respawn (until the endgame) its really the only choice. Though that in itself is a good thing, I just wish the side-missions felt a little more fun and engaging.Despite all this, I would reccommend D2 to a friend, because the main storyline itself, is very engaging and quite good. I hope Larian (the developers) will make a D3 and get the backing of a larger publishing company so they can use the additional resources and time that they deserve for their works.

												Game has it's strong points, but I am reviewing this in the light of its combat. I only played the melee build and I personally think its terrible. Why? first off, well you can't really use the shield to block. You just use it only as a secondary weapon that adds armor which defeats the purpose of the thing. Second, it lacks any depth whatsover and just wants you to click click click to win. Sure dodging and jumping is there, but the usefulness of those mechanics only truly shine against ranged enemies. Also, if you have a low-end PC and expect to handle this game well because it's old, Don't. The game runs terribly with my laptop, and my laptop handled skyrim decently to say the least. Overall, if you want to play for the story, go do it. it's worth it. But me being a combat centered fella, I cannot recommend this. (You can turn into a dragon tho so thats cool)

18, 2016
												I know I didn't get far into the game, but what I did play was the most absolutely bland experience. Music, quests, skill system, battle system, world map. Nothing was one bit appealing; it just felt like a bunch of low-effort implementation of necessary mechanics. They weren't bad, really, but nothing seemed the least bit *good*. If this game were a meal, it would be plain rice and soggy vegetables, and a shapeless chunk of lean ground beef cooked medium-well. With water on the side. I have no troubles eating these food items, but without anything special being added to the plate, I would never wish to eat it as a meal.The one outlier was the animations. Absolute negative for me. From walking to jumping, spellcasting to talking, everything the characters did made me want to gauge out my eyeballs. Oh, and also the main menu felt like it was locked at 15-20fps. Increasing frame rate cap did nothing to help it, but the ingame was just fine.It's kind of sad because the story seemed like it would be pretty good if I could trudge through the painfully mundane game.

ry 11, 2016
												Okay I played Divinity 2 Ego Draconis for the Xbox 360. It had so many game breaking bugs that there is no way it was tested, at all. I bought this game hoping the PC version would play better I mean you can patch a PC version alot more right? Apparently not. If my first few seconds in the PC version is any indicator to how less broken the game is (froze in place and crashed) I'm opting out and I would suggest you do too.Ignoring all the game breaking bugs I LOVED the idea of this game. However the execution outside of the bugs leaves a LOT to be desired. The dificulty curve is terrible early on. You'll be getting stomped on everywhere you go. The whole becoming a dragon thing won't happen till the halfway point of the game, and then it's rather underwhelming, and you start getting stomped on again at this point cause now you're a bigger target. that can't attack much more than before.Also the game felt very Stingy with Exp. I had to squeze out every quest I could find to level up later on and I can't remember if was because enemies don't respawn or cause they don't give exp. I don't know, if you REALLY want to buy this game be prepared for a LOT of bugs and looking for solutions to them online. Also SAVE very often and on a LOT of different slots because there are some bugs that can break your entire file and will keep happening unless you reload to a very specific point before that bug hits.

content:
y 20
												I really wanted to and tried to like this game because it is part of the Divinity series but its just fails to be entertaining or worthwhile. It's an ARPG with bad and sloppy combat, and the majority of gameplay is endless tedious trudging through generic cartoonish uninteresting MMO themepark landscapes that suffer from invisible wall syndrome. The dragon flight mode is a painful chore. At times the quest system and narrative does a completely inadequate job at explaining things and not in a good way.Maybe the console version was more responsive, but there's no native controller support on PC. That might be acceptable for an action-oriented title of its age if it's mouse/keyboard control weren't so sloppy. It's just not responsive enough for an action RPG, and even using it with the Steam Controller cannot fix the underlying problems. It doesn't work as an action title and there's not enough meat on the bones for it to stand alone as an RPG.There is some good to be said about it which is why I tried to stick with it so long. It has really compelling and polished weapon, armor, magic and skill progression and loot systems. A game built around those alone could be really good. Too bad they feel completely wasted on the rest of this game. Voice acting and music is passable, and there are some really good ideas such as being able to build a companion creature out of parts, and the staff of various servants at your base.The generic writing and quests might have been adequate enough if the game held up as an action title with decent combat, but at least on PC it does not, leaving no real reason to keep playing.

You often find yourself with no quests in the todo list and need to wander in the map until you stumble upon the quest giver. Stay away.

												This is a pretty shallow game, not sure why it's getting such great reviews but Original Sin is vastly superior from what I played at a friend's. I selected to play as a Mage (after the game failed to really explain what I was supposed to do). So far I feel like it's a lot of pretty bland combat, dull quests and shabby voice acting. There's little world-building and you can barely interact with any of it save for some plants and the animals/monsters you kill. There's not much in the way of dialogue and not a lot to keep you interested in this generic high fantasy world with limited skills and almost zero explanation of how your skill tree/spells work. That's all without mentioning the complete lack of character customisation. I don't feel I'm really playing any role except for errand boy here.If you want some mindless grindy action and running back and forth there's this and that Reckoning game that people also liked, but if you want something a bit richer then try Divinity: Original Sin, which was rad.

content:
y 8, 2016
												This is a terrible game that I can't recommend to anyone. It's clearly not finished. It has no story or plot whatsoever (I have no clue what the story and goal is, after playing for hours on end). It has cookie-cutter enemies throughout. Quests are boring and confusing at best. The dialogue is laughable, in a bad sense. There are strange and unexplained castles in the sky that contain only enemies and no quests and no relevant loot. Why are they at all in the game? Just for levelling up? That's not an RPG. That's a chore. As a dragon my avatar can't see and attack enemies on land, but when I convert it back to a human they suddenly pop up from nowhere. I could go on and on.It looked and behaved great early on, but it seems the developers got bored of it and threw it out the door as fast as they could.I played Arcania (and its expansion) just before, that was excellent in comparison. A true gem in the rough. Try that instead.For a game that handles human/dragon conversions the right way, check out Drakan. It's not an RPG (more a medieval shooter) and it's certainly not new, but it's brilliant in comparison to Divinity II, despite its dated graphics.Even at bargain bin price this game is awful.Update: I'm playing the expansion now and my avatar is at level 43. Despite this, and the fact that I have two companions and playing on Casual, I can't even put a dent on an arena full of monsters (20 or more) where all can heal themselves, and where I only have 90 seconds or so to finish. If I can't I have to watch a long sequence about my avatar being locked in (forever?), so after a while I just force-stopped the game and restarted. Again and again... Actually I did finish it once, but as the game locks up every time it changes scene, I had to replay anyway, which might happen again next time I possibly succeed.Again, a god awful game, suitable for masochists.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												Divinity 2 is a remastered version of Ego Draconis featuring new content with an enhanced engine packaged with an add-on Flames of Vengeance (FOV). The 2 games form a complete story when played together.Personally it took me 45 hours to finish the 2 games, and this is taking into account that i had skipped alot of side quests and even referred to a walkthrough for some of the puzzles. If you were to do everything and experience all the game had to offer, it will probably take you close to 80 to 90 hours or even more.The first starting village you entered had a surprisingly huge amount of sidequests. The problem is, most of them just aren't very interesting, and most of the time, instead enjoying the story in the sidequest, alot of them felt more like merely items in a checklist that has to be finished off just for the rewards.The main problem i feel though, the whole game just doesn't take itself very seriously. It tries to tell an epic story but the execution just feels amatuerish. (Was it really necessary to re-introduce the player character in FOV via a parody of the movie "The Terminator"?)The character animations are very rough and almost all characters you talk to tend to like to flail their arms wildly in the air in a very exaggerated style. Its as if they were thinking if they make the NPCs move their arms more, they would look more alive lol. Its really funny to see an esteemed Knight Commander talking to you and flailing his arms wildly in the air like a mad loon. Alot of the NPC faces are also re-used and you will see quite alot of similar looking faces everywhere.Voice acting is noticeably bad, and alot of them either sound bored, over-enthusiastic, or just plain silly. Music is a mixed bag, with some tunes feeling suitably atmospheric, and some tunes that won't sound out of place in a James Bond movie lol.The main selling point of the game is to be able to turn into a dragon and fly anywhere. But this concept isn't as exciting as it sounds. For one thing, the world is not truly open-world and fully explorable. There are alot of invisible walls everywhere. And you will not have the pleasure of morphing into a dragon and burning down all the enemies on the ground. They just magically disappear when you morph into dragon mode which i suppose was to not imbalance the gameplay. Still it would have been nicer if they were able to combine the 2 into a seamless experience instead of the current system that they had.One particular feature that i enjoyed was Mindreading, which basically lets you listen to the thoughts of NPCs. Its a very nice idea, as you can sometimes get extra rewards or even new quests with it. But again, they had to put a silly penalty of requiring EXP to actually do mind reading. Personally i felt that it was really unnecessary to do this, to punish the player's level progress while he checks out something cool with an NPC.The ending of Ego Draconis is also very controversial and suffice to say, basically undermines everything you have done, and is one of the worst endings IMO in an RPG. The add-on Flames of Vengeance(FOV) corrects this however, and provides better closure. I am aware that FOV came 11 months after the Ego Draconis, and i have a gut feeling that it was crafted to pacify the players who have been crying foul of the original ending.It may look like i am bashing the game, but i really am not. There is an interesting game in there somewhere, but only if you are willing to endure the amatuerish style it is presented. Maybe thats the way this RPG is meant to be enjoyed, a funny little game with some movie parodies that doesn't take itself very seriously.Overall Rating: 6.0 / 10If you are willing to overlook its many faults, this is still a worthy purchase if on sale.

content:
14, 2015
												I saw the trailers and the other reviews to this game. I was hyping myself to play this. It looked genuinely fun to be able to become a dragon and be an unstoppable force of death. Unfortunately my experience was less so.The game is excruciatingly difficult for beginners. Even more infuriating is the difficulty ramp itself and the fact that to my knowlege, enemies do not respawn. I thought i would do some sidequests to level up quicker but nearly all of them are in areas far above my level. and that added to the fact enemies dont respawn makes leveling a difficult task.Potions are also abnormaly rare, at least when i played. I would find myself in a horde of enemies and use up all of my potions before even reaching the boss to a dungeon or area.One boss named jagon was so infuriatingly impossible to defeat that i resorted to cheating to beat him. That may sound like it was unnecessary, but I was not allowed to leave the dungeon unless i beat jagon! I couldnt level up because the enemies would not respawn and the entrance was locked. I would have been stuck in that dungeon unless i reverted to a save that was well in the past. Me and Jagon were both level 11.I really wanted to like this game. I read that it becomes much funner and easier after you become a fully realized dragon slayer. But I was at a point of almost zero tolerance for the game. It does not help that the UI, combat, and level design are all angering and not very streamlined. I have spent almost 20 minutes walking up and down hallways to find levers or buttons to doors that are locked for seemingly no reason.tldr; This game made me furious while i tried to have fun.

content:
0, 2015
												I tried to like this game i really did but i just could not being myself to find anything i actually could like about this particular title except the voice acting. There are a great many reasons why i think this game falls short but one of the biggest is the set system.Now to begin the list in no real order.1) The textures are horribly done, they other do not fit in the environment they are in properly or just plain look terrible.2) The one that annoyed me most durring gameplay: the reflective surfaces being too high on metal armors (meaning armor shines too much when exposed to light such as the sun).3) The storyline starts out good but turns so generic it bored me.4) The skill tree is horribly unbalanced, which includes the 4 classes being unbalanced. being a melee class is pretty much useless, same with being a summoner. So your best bet is to major in being a mage or ranger as a main class and take knight as a subclass.5) The horribly written books in the game gives no encouragement for collectors like myself especially considering how late your personal storage is introduced, which means if you do want to collect the books you need to waste valuable skill points on weight capacity, however honestly whats the point? Most of the normal books are terribly boring to read.6) With the combination of xp level range system, monsters almost never dropping anything, absolutely no monster regen, and that includes boars. There is almost no incentive to visit previously missed areas unless you find out there is a set piece there.In closing i would like to say for the most part this game is mostly Gothic and Drakengaurd put together but a bad attempt at both, of course there are elements of other games as well. There are elements of Diablo as you have no doubt noticed. The dragon combat was one of the worst dragon combat systems i have ever seen honestly... it was slow and highly restricted on where you could go.

content:
, 2015
												I'm very split about how to review this game, but ultimately I would not recommend it for the time being. The story is very good, the environment is gorgeous, the world and lore feels a lot more developed than a lot of ARPGs, etc., but the game does suffer from a lot of bugs and other issues which seem to get progressively worse the longer you play. The gameplay is decent and has its own flaws and quirks. This game has a huge amount of potential but seems to become more and more unplayable. I really want to play this game more, but it's just too broken. I reached about 30 hours in before the game got to where I just can't progress any further. I've tried using previous save files, but some bugs still get triggered and it's not worth repeating hours of the game to see whether the bugs show up or not. I really want to recommend this game because of how much I enjoyed what I could play, but it's just way too buggy.I've encountered several bugs which range from annoying to completely game breaking. The longer I play, the worse the frame rate becomes, to the point I have to save and restart the game. The only issue is, the frame rate has gotten permanently slower no matter what settings I try. When I first started the game would be about 60FPS (at the cap) but has fallen to average somewhere between 20-30FPS (sometimes falling as low as 10FPS for no real reason) even in the same areas I got 60FPS before. It doesn't seem to be an issue with my computer, but a bug in the game itself since it only really happens with this game and several other buggy games. Certain cutscenes will also crash the game randomly.I've also had a bunch of random physics and control bugs which aren't too bad but are extremely annoying. I've managed to clip into things and come close to sequence breaking from issues with the physics. If you land on certain objects (things which you can very easily jump on), you can get stuck to the point of having to reload a save file. Sometimes the game will freak out and the controls lock up or get stuck performing the same action if you perform an action while moving or if you use a spell while attacking. If I use the dragon's flame attack and cast a spell, sometimes the dragon will get stuck attacking with flames, and be unable to move left or right, until I click several times. I've had several other issues during combat where my character gets left unable to move or attack and the camera stays locked until I cast a spell (it isn't a status effect), but I can't figure out exactly what triggers it. The dragon form targeting seems to have broken permanently in my game and will randomly jump between targets on the screen (literally all of them) even without moving (mouse or keyboard) and with stationary enemies being the only thing on screen.Certain quests have been rendered impossible because of bugs as well. The General Raze fight is impossibly bugged on my game. The first time I played I ended up dying as I opened the menu, then I reloaded from an earlier save and the Walking Armour spawns were broken. If I reload from any previous save and work back to that point, the spawns are still broken. The number of spawn points has doubled (the healing pods spawn them), each spawn point spawns about the same number of things that the whole room did before the bug (could be more, hard to tell since they spawn inside each other), and the delay time dropped to somewhere between 10 and 15 seconds or so per round of spawns. They spawn so fast and with so many that it is quite literally impossible to kill them all. They continue spawning in the same spot past the point the game AI stops trying to control new spawns. The dragon form seems to have broken on my game after resetting my skill points since it doesn't get any increase in health or other stats when my character levels up. I do get random dragon skill points every couple levels for some reason though... Certain battles which require dragon form have glitches with enemies spawning, like the Zagan fight, where the other things keep spawning even when the nest towers are all dead. There are other minor bugs like certain quests where you choose who to give something to or whatever are either both completable or both incompletable depending on the savefile (played through the first 2 hours like 3 times on different files, had the first savefile be completable for both options for an early quest, normal choice the second, and incompletable the third). I've also failed to find certain NPCs which are supposed to be in certain areas, I don't know if these have been because of any kind of bug or just not hitting the right trigger.The gameplay is overall very fluid and fun, albeit extremely unforgiving. If you level properly and fight very strategically, you can get extremely overleveled very early on. Of course, the game is unforgiving with your stat points so if you plan poorly, you can completely gimp your character until you get a lot more stat points. Combat is pretty easy to follow though it is easy to get overwhelmed depending on what kind of character you play. Certain parts of the combat system can get annoying, like enemies healing faster than you can kill them, no real blocking mechanic, and other minor glitches. The biggest drawback in the gameplay is the fact the difficulty ramps up pretty harshly with very little warning. It's usually possible to take on higher level foes if you're used to playing with Dark Souls style tactics and can lure enemies away. Certain areas are almost impossible without coming back later even if they should be the right level for you to beat. Tricking the enemy into falling off the map or knocking them off doesn't seem to net you experience though, which can ruin certain areas since enemies don't respawn.The story, lore and environment are what really shine in this game. The story itself is a pretty stereotypical bad guy turned hero type thing, but the way it's told is what makes it actually good and not just a complete cookie cutter type scenario. Lore seems to be mainly divided into books and interactions with people. People in towns don't always have something important to say but usually have something unique. You have NPCs who feel more alive than most RPG NPCs. Towns feel like they're filled with people rather than just reskinned NPCs from the town back. NPCs also feel like they have personalities; their motivation for their actions aren't just good or evil. You also have choices to make that aren't just black and white, good or evil, but hinge on personal judgement. You can try and glean more information from other NPCs but the choices are almost never obviously good or bad, but just different which is a nice change of pace. I don't know how it ends since my game broke too badly to really hope to complete, but it was definitely building up pretty awesomely.

content:
y 4, 2015
												tl;dr  If you can get it for a few quid in a sale maybe worth it, if not, don't bother.Starts out well as a semi open-world combat orientated third person RPG, however quickly runs into problems outside the starting area. The combat quickly becomes a repetitve grind (think WoW but single player) interspaced with frustrating boss fights. Ranged builds will suffer from many fights taking place in mines or corridors with locked doors and no room to maneourve, while melee builds will get demolished by spell and arrow spamming packs of mobs. The vaunted dragon-form combat is a glorified fast travel system since while in dragon form you can't attack "ground level" enemies; forcing you to try and slug it out in human regardless of the situation. Likewise although the game has a relatively large number of skills most of them are either useless or don't work in important fights.

												A surprisingly solid 3D RPG that taps all the usual fantasy tropes (wizards, dragons, fighters/mages/rangers, bandits, goblins, backwards villagers with west country accents) that just about manages to keep the fetch/kill quests fresh by chucking in a bunch of new gameplay mechanics about half-way through the game.The Developer's Cut is an amalgamation of the original game (Ego Draconis), the expansion (Flames of Vengeance) and some random fluff (design docs, concept art and dev's console for 'cheating'). Pick it up if it's on sale.

r 6, 2014
												After 15 hours of game play and finally making it to the battle tower I have to stop playing this game. It's OK and has some good parts and bad parts to it. The items are Random, Skill point and abilities are intresting and I like the clunky combat thos very easy to exploit and somewhat easy. The bad parts of this game is the lack of character debth and plot development. The main bad guy is not intresting at all and I would go as far as to say he's "lame"  to quote some 80's computer slang. Once you get to the battle tower the game opens put, for some games this a good thing, for Divinity 2 it's a bad thing as I have no motivation to continue on, I suspect there will be no amazing cut scenes I will miss, no new intresting characters and most importantly getting to this point of them game has been unfulfilling.  If you absoutly have nothing to play for whatever reason...if it was 1996 again, if you are trapped on an island and this is the only game on a computer... then I would say Divinity 2 would be a pretty good game. With games like D&D, Elder Scrolls, Fallout, Borderlands, batman, battlefeild, most jrpg's, Dragon age...diablo, dungeon defenders, anything intresting on your ipad, kingdom rush free on kongragate, board game nights with friends, munchkin! poker! and many many more activities.... their is no real reason to put your time here.

												Just some of my thoughts on the game, not very organized.Mechanically its pretty decent, I could see its mechanics being used to make a great game, with a few things changed, like how people say that enimies disapear when you play as a dragon, I never got to the point where I could change into one. Plus the combat could be a lot better, melee is much harder than archery or magic, but its still fun if you want a challenge. Try doing a playthrough only using your fists.I do enjoy playing it when I wan't mindless combat, but the story is pretty boring and feels like it doesn't take itself seriously, but its not done well enough where its actually amusing and fun. The aesthetics are generally pretty ok but some of the things are jarring, the spandex armor for the ladies is : \ and I find the wizard dudes clothes feel very generic.The story is, forgettable and generic.There is little facial customization, which is something I look for in my open world games where they aren't single character and story driven, I much prefer skyrims over divinities.Its fun to do backflips everywhere.The music is nice.Get it if you want a mindless romb through generic fantasy land with bonus changing into dragons.

												This game was good and bad the graphics are great. the story is interesting but the fights are few and far between and not remotely a challenge. by the time you get your armor set and enchant it the way you want it there isn't anything left to kill. the developers cut doesn't let you create your own levels or games it only lets you cheat and add the much needed monsters that are absent from the original. if you play ego draconis by the time you get to the second chapter of the game you are already a god and there isn't a challenge left. content:
14
												Wow this is going to be a pain in the ♥♥♥ to review. If i just played The first half of the game i would have given this game a thumbs up, but after flames of vengence the problems are just way too big to ignore. For the review i am going to list off all of the good stuff and the bad stuff, then really get into the horrors that await to be explained.Pro's-humorous characters-decent music- about a hundered side quests-dragon mode (Really fun but needs more work-armor and weapon sets that boost stats-refrences to divine divinity and beyond divinity- Mindreading is innovative- necromancy is available for all classes and becomes a mechanic in the game-puzzles and jumping puzzles- some enemy designs are really bizarre and crazy-refrences to other mediaCons-combat is ♥♥♥-the story sucks so bad, that the sidequests stand out even more-Character creation sucks- starts out really slow and generic like any other rpg-crafting sucks- leveling up sucks (no in depth skill tree that can branch off other skills)- no lockpicking game like in the elder-scrolls-no memorable characters- YOU CANT BEAT THE FINAL BOSS WITHOUT CHEATS BECAUSE YOU GET INSTANTLY ♥♥♥♥♥ IN 2 SECONDS BY A STUN. AND A OVERKILL AMOUNT OF DAMAGE OFF OF 1 HIT, NOT TO MENTION THAT THIS HAPPENS TWICE.Time to go in depth about the problems. the game is split into two parts, eco draconis, and flames of vengence. They were sold as two seperate games in 2009-2010. But later on in 2012 they created the developers edition: both games packaged as one, with the addition of cheats, and console commands. Both games final boss stages are impossible to beat with any build, or any skill because you holster your weapon every time you go into diologue, the final boss's first attack is also a stagger or a polymorph (which makes you stand still for 1 second) then they hit you with an instakill.both final boss stages of ego draconis, and flames of vengeance are impossible to beat without god mode. That right there is absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I would be fine if it was just a sidequest, but imagine if skyrim's main story or any dragon age game's story was impossible to beat without cheats. To be honest i would give this a neutral thumb if steam let me give it, but my final hours of both 2 games were spent trying to finish it as soon as possible, so that i could stop playing that horrible main story. If i could beat the final boss's without cheats the game would have recieved the thumbs up. As it stand now, It is a poor mans KOA ReckoningGo buy kingdoms of amalor reckoning if you want a third person rpg, or spend your money on larian studio's better games in the divinity franchise such as: divine divinity, divinity original sin 1 and 2.

												Played quite a bit through it.At the time, years ago, when it came out I was incredibly hyped for this. Who doesn't want a good RPG? We still don't have many. However I was only able to get it like I dunno months ago whenever I played it. The world is good and creative. Also taking good spins on the typical things you see in other medieval/knights worlds.People bash the game for it's graphics, which to today's standards are incredibly poor, but at the time they weren't that bad. They were okay at best. The game has good promise, but it's such a shame the company was so small and lacked so many resources at the time. I'd like a reboot of this to be honest. It lacks a lot of polish. For example I mean you can only choose between brown or blonde hair at the character creation screen. I'm not serious. They cut a lot of corners just to bring out a fresh and original world and game concepts. Such as being a dragon etc. It lacks a lot but it's got such good heart. It's hard to recommend unless you are a diehard fan of RPGs, because then you judge purely on the story, characters and world etc.

												Would love to recommend this game.  I originally bought and played Draconis, and loved it.  Flames of Vengence is awful though.  Running around, random, no-direction questing in a city.  The end is the nail in the coffin - an escort mission.  I can confidently say _many_ people _HATE_ escort missions, and I do.  I wish I had never bought the developers cut ($5 for the whole thing was too tempting).  This "complete" game served only to sour my high opinion on Draconis.It's worth noting - 97 hours total for the game.  Less than 15 of those hours were in FoV, and the remainder were in Draconis.

content:
y 5, 2015
												I can't really recommend this game. There are things I like in the game, but it basically throws you into the fray with little to no instruction on the mechanics. It's also really difficult to tell where your loyalities lay you start out with one faction then through a (chance?) encounter you end up as an enemy of your first faction also one min you're doing quests for a faction then next quest you're killing those same guys pretty confusing.  The game also has a pretty annoying tendency to corrupt it's files, the only solution I've found if to clear local content and reinstall (I've done this like 4 or 5 times  in the last week or so, it's a 2 to 3 hr process each time). I tried using the backup feature from steam (thinking if I had a local copy the reinstall might go faster), which oddly doesn't seem to have a restore option (Why?).The game designers I think are certifiably Sadistic. Two interesting puzzles that seemed to have no point or solution.First is in a mine, where you find yourself playing jumpy jumpy games climbing a wall to reach a plaftorm that has a lever on it. Ok well I have no Idea why such ar room would be in a mine first of all, but then the fireballs started, what idiot would shoot flame in a mine? Don't the developers know that there are explosive gases below ground open flame is not recommended and these guys are throwing fireballs. Go figure. Oh and here is the best part you finally reach the level you pull it and 2 new platforms appear but they only stay visible (usable) for about 10 seconds 5 of which is burned up by a cutaway scene that leaves you rooted in place. Needless to say I never solved it.The other realls sadistic one also involves platforms you have to jump to, presumably to find the leaver that tuens off a Necromancer's force field. Great except it's all overtop of a pool of lava, I jumped ot like the second platform and it fell and gave me the interesting experience of dieing in a vat of lava. I finally decided I really didn't want to turn off that forcefield all that badly.So, the long and the short of it I payed like $6 for the trilogy (on sale). Thank goodness because if I'd paid any more than that I'd be pretty poed by now. Get this game only if you have a high tolerance for frustration.

												Another game with a lot of potential that falls flat on its face right out of the gate.  I can only assume that based on the reviews it is possible to enjoy the game if you get past the horrible issues up front.  The main problem is, you choose one of three "classes" by way of testing them out in an open area on some goblins.  Ok cool, I decided ranger is good, I like plinking with a bow, the mage has jack for spells and instead just clubs things up close.  Then after the into movie, a whole lot of chatting with folks, pick up a few side quests that seem awkwardly thrown in, and get sent into a crypt as the first main storyline quest.  And get jumped by 3 skeletons of higher level than I am and are no match for a bow.  Seems you can ONLY choose warrior to start the game, nothing else, and then use the other classes later.  Sorry, but blowing an hour to find out I have to start all over says I have no time for what is likely to be a seriously flawed game.  Toss in how awkward a lot of it feels, and then the voice acting... I mean half of it is really good, the other half is worse than a sci-fi original movie, it's painful to listen to.

content:
er 15, 2016
												Good voice-acting. Female NPCs with pretty faces. Watch your player character in underwear, if you take off every piece of armor. The background music doesn't match the atmosphere always.I've enjoyed the initial exploration in a rather restricted area (aka "Broken Valley") that seemed interesting enough. And I've enjoyed the blind flight, because I was playing carefully and without following any guides or walkthroughs.Then I've struggled during the second half. Tedious, dull, repetitive drudgery to attempt a completionist playthrough in order to be able to reach high levels. And even then the experience points mechanics require a variety of special tricks to turn in quest XP at the right time and kill enemies in the right order for more XP. Nevertheless, eventually I almost felt over-powered due to the high level and access to tons of special equipment. The occasional balancing issues made a very few minor boss fights unexpectedly difficult, and I assure you, there are players, who "rage quit" the game in such a situation. You can always search for help or hints, but be prepared to find unhelpful comments from either braggarts, or from people, who only know the older release of this game.Haven't run into crashes or obvious bugs. Except in the heat of combat, sometimes either my mouse stopped accepting camera rotation input. Or music stopped playing. Quicksave and quickload fixed it directly during combat.And finally, I've run into a game-breaking bug that is known for years, unfortunately. It's been discussed before. I've mentioned it in the forum, too, before writing this review. An enemy four levels below me, who kills me either with the first magic attack I cannot avoid or with the next attack a second later. There are videos, where that doesn't happen. There are players, who play the game with half the health points and with many more wasted skill points. But there are reports that describe exactly the same problem that can cause real frustration.It seems, the players of this edition of the game are supposed to fire up the game in the separate developer mode and activate a cheat mode to work around that problem. Not sexy at all.Edit #1: A bit later, the same bug apparently also affected another important fight and made it almost impossible even with lots of cheat modes activated. Enemies moved too quickly and were much too resistant to damage to stop them as required during that fight where they approach from three directions and respawn, too. Again, when searching the web about it, I see the same reports by other players and also videos where the enemies move much slower and can be eliminated with ease. Here it seemed impossible even with godlike cheats, multiple summons and holding down the key to launch magical area attacks all the time. Whatever it is that messed up my game on "Normal" difficulty so late, it's the opposite of fun.Edit #2: In the end, I've decided not to turn off the cheat modes anymore for the final fight. The frustrating experience has been too much of a motivation killer, and I've also decided against continueing into the add-on due to this.

content:
, 2014
												It's not a /bad/ game per se. But it's not worth its price, unless you're buying it on a Steam sale, like I did. The general concept of the storyline is rather decent, yes, and the graphics and general gameplay are, to quote one cartoon character, "pretty pretty shiny shiny" but the game falls flat on its face when you get to the last 10% of the Ego Draconis campaign and Flames of Vengeance does very little to fix it. The... *cough* twist at the end effectively murders the plot, reducing it to "just barely not terrible" in one fell swoop. It's difficult to put it without spoilers, but let's just say that the plot as a general whole until that point becomes entirely irrelevant and your decisions, it suddenly turns out, make no difference to the ending.What's worse, Flames of Vengeance, the expansion that should have reputedly saved us all, actually makes it worse by having that /plot twist/ at the end of Ego Draconis have no real effect on the world, aside from you feeling mildly uncomfortable. If it was supposed to fix the disappointing ending of Ego Draconis, it only made the situation worse. Larian somehow managed, in one grandiloquent failure, to ruin the entire game just as it was ending. More painfully than Bioware in Mass Effect 3, I'd say.

content:
er 5, 2014
												This game has difficulty spikes that were supposed to have been fixed in the Dragon Knight Saga patch. It is unbearably painful to play in these difficulty spike areas, given how generic the combat is no matter how dumb the AI acts. This game starts off painfully to the point that I wouldn't recommend it, no matter what happens later on in the game, simply because it is too frustrating to get past the initial hurdle. If you want to play this game, know full well that it is easy to break a character build that will be unable to progress past future enemies, a flaw that they attempted to fix by cutting down enemy health and damage. Larian studios, although making improvements to their combat in their newer titles, completely failed here and left a mediocre combat system in this game. If you want to make a game functional, don't start off a player's stats at 1, this is not an mmo, though they certainly designed it to feel like one for the basic human character. At these stat levels, it was bound to happen that they would encounter problems balancing enemy levels and stats early on. On a plus, you at least have cool combat animations.The jumping mechanic is glitchy at best, don't blame yourself if you jump in a stream and cannot get out easily. The ending is garbage and cliche, you spend the entire game listening to cutscenes of the villain making grandiose speeches in front of you. The expansion also has a mediocre ending, although it at least makes you happier than the base game with its conclusion. The engine is on par with TES Morrowind, but many times less enjoyable or memorable. The dragon mechanic is a cheap gimmick halfway through the game, with completely uninspired flight mechanics and nominal mmo interfacing. I can guarantee that half of the positive reviews are waxing nostalgia for the franchise, which is deserved given how much better its previous titles merit. Absolutely the worst of the franchise, skip it if you don't want to be screwed over by the story and forced through repetitive and pointless gameplay. The only upside is that the side quests are at least original and interesting in the choices you can make, never painting a black and white picture.I honestly do not know how people tolerate this game to play it through. The core game is entirely flawed, such that there is a limited pool of XP, nothing respawns, you literally have to beat every side quest to have the XP to make a good character build. There is nothing enjoyable about the combat, it even takes away from the enjoyment of playing the game. It is a torture to try and beat the game when you are instantly dying because you didn't pick the boilerplate max stat character build. This game had so much potential, the combat engine ruined it entirely for me. I'm glad I got this on sale for less than three dollars, it is not worth anything more. I don't hate games often, but this has caused me serious grief and I regret every minute I spent playing it.Before the Dragon Knight Saga, this game got between a 6 and a 7 on many review sites. Even with the Dragon Knight Saga, it still deserves the mediocre score, and nothing can redeem this game besides a complete re-make.

content:
er 2, 2014
												Passable game, nothing really remarkable or new about it, just like so many other rather unknown RPGs out there.In Divinity 2 you play, at least initially, as a Dragon Slayer novice. You hunt dragons for a living. The game starts with you and your crew picking up the trail of the very last Dragon Knight known to mankind. As you start to track the beast down, Damian, the game's antagonist, is closing the siege on some of the last bastions of human civilization. His goal is to enslave or eradicate every living person and control the world with his power. All pretty standard so far.The amazing part of the game is that, spoiler alert, you get to become a Dragon Knight, transform into a dragon and fly your way around. That takes a while, though. Like, fifteen to twenty hours of gameplay. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.The rest of the game is all about looking for the fabled Hall of Echoes, where you'll adquire knowledge on how to defeat Damian and stop his ultimate goal: The revival of some old-♥♥♥ dragon mother.Gameplay is actually pretty fun, action oriented and all that. Most of you will be quite familiar with the type. My grudge with this game is that it adds absolutely nothing new to the table and has a colossally mediocre story, which for a RPG is something quite important. The game may be worth buying and playing if you got nothing else to play. Other than that, it's not worth it.Gameplay - 6/10Soundtrack - 5/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 7/10Challenge Level - 7/10Replayability - 2/10

content:
, 2014
												Do not get this game if you are expecting to be able to turn into a dragon and rain fireballs down on your enemies. Once you turn into a dragon, all the land-based enemies literally disappear. The dragon form is really *only* for moving to out-of-reach locations. While flying you have to destory towers, ballistas, nests, and flying enemies, which I found lacking. It was an awesome idea, but it did not deliver.The story is pretty good, the gameplay is decent (I found the jump a little annoying to control at times since you jump so high), and levelling up is fun. It has a stat-based system.I found the skill tree lacking. I only played as a mage, which was fun; however, there is only one spammable spell - magic missile. Other attack spells have cool-downs, which is alright, but some more variety would have been nice. One good thing about the skills are that you can mix and match to make your character however you want and you can respec at a relatively low cost about half-way through the game.I'm probably not going to play the expansion. I've read that it is pretty good, but I think I'm ready to finish the last area and uninstall.

content:
r 16, 2014
												Divinity II: Director's Cut. Right out of the gate, I was pretty unimpressed. The cut scenes were glorious, but then, cut scenes often are, and this, unlike DragoneAge 2, doesn't really live in the cut scenes. I had been excited about character creation though, so ... moving on to that. Pick a gender. Pick one of 4 heads. One of four hair colors. One of four voices. You're done. Really? They might as well have just handed me a pregen. VERY disappointing. Well, maybe the mechanics will be amazing. Moving on to the obligatory turt-orial. Annnd- the game locked up just as I was attempting to stroll through the gates into TutorialTown (Farglow.) Looked for info online, found very little bug-fix/tech help available at all, but finally tracked down the advice to crank my gfx to min, which worked, but the reason I bought it was because it promised to be glorious and graphical so... as soon as I got past the hiccup, I cranked them up again, and it seemed to be fine after that. Well. Fine- ISH, anyway. Again- I bought it to take pretty pictures. It has no way to turn off the UI hud, and a locked cam. So screenshots are an immediate disappoint. Ah well. And still, I rest my hopes on the game mechanics, so again, moving on. Tutorial town- They hand me glowing eyes, tell me I can read minds now, (but it costs xp to do so,) offer me merchants with a lot of gear I can't come close to affording, and tell me I can pick one of 3 classes. If I';m a ranger, I can use a bow, a warrior can use a sword and leap around impressively, and a mage can throw colorful sparks. Uhm... This is feeling more and more like a glorified platformer by the minute. Ran around, talked to some folks, discovered that the dialog is at least moderately adult- they toss in colorful epithets like "♥♥♥" and "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s" so it's for grown-ups I guess. And the soundtrack is just... BIZARRE. Again, reminiscent of 8-bit techno. It was... different, I'll give it that! Fought some goblins. Died. Didn't feel inspired to waste more of my day on it. 4 out of ten, if you want thumbs or stars or something. Not hugely impressed with Dinvinity II. Glad I only paid 6 bucks for it.
