content:
11, 2014
												Where to start. I got this game when it first came out on the Xbox: 360. I was kind of disapointed. I mean the game was quite buggy, laggy and just had it problems. Needless to say, I returned it and got something else. Not I see it on sale and decide, why not give it another try. Well I did and I can say its not so laggy, or course I have a gaming machine now that can handle it. Anyways, the storyline isnt that bad, I'm not super far into it, but it's rather interesting. However, this game can be brutally hard. I recommend to save often. And when I say often, I mean before a battle, after a battle, and every other step. If you don't become a ranger/mage, and save up your money for a really powerful bow, your gonna have a hard time. The difficulty spikes in this game can be ridiculous.I've always been a warrior type. Love to go in and battle my enemies toe-to-toe. But in this game, It's so hard to do that, especially when you get ganged up by 5+ people at once. Even with good armor, they can shread through your health like butter. But in this game, I had to do ranged just to get by. And some quests require you to go into some difficult areas, usually above your level.However, this game does have its interesting bits. The story is interesting to say the least with your choices having an effect on the world around you and even what price people sell their goods for. Having the choice to decide peoples fates, or to have my actions matter is something I love about a game. The NPCs in the game are also quite welll done. Every NPC has it's own name, characteristics, and converstions. Each thinking something different that may help you in a quest, or with getting lower proces at shops.The skill system I can say however is nicely done. You don't have to dwell in just your calss based stats. You can be a battle ready warrior shooting fireballs and summoning creatures, to an unarmed mage beating his enimies to a pulp.All in all, with the crazy difficulty spikes, the somewhat "ok" story, and the just barely getting around, I can't recommend this game. The skill system was great, and the NPC's are wonderful, but the combat difficulty is what ruins it. It's an ok game, but not great. You can give it a try, and you may love it.

content:
ber 21, 2016
												This game is just bad. I wanted to wait until I had more hours into the game, or had completed it, but I find it so unenjoyable that I don't think that I can. Other reviewers have compared it to Risen, and they're not really incorrect. From the screenshots, I originally decided not to buy this game, but eventually the positive reviews and cover art convinced me. One of the best words I can use to describe this game is clumsy.To list some of it's problems; It has grossly exaggerated animations, the audio is really imbalanced, for example, the player character's voice is very loud, and certain effects such as fireball sounds are very loud, yet npc dialogue is very quiet, and the music alternates in different tracks between too loud and too quiet, combat is really awkward, it reminds me of mmos, yet not as balanced, it acutally has platforming sections despite the controls and especially the player's ridiculous jump being, again, clumsy, it constantly jumps to cutscenes, for which it sheaths the player's weapons and then jumps immediatly to combat, forcing you to draw your weapons again while being attacked, when it didn't make any sense to sheath them in the first place, the enemy AI is braindead, the story and characters feel generic and predictable, moments of significance are handled carelessly with little to no regard for attempting to impress the player or make transitions feel significant, and I feel like it demands too much attention from the player when the game isn't enjoyable or rewarding in the first place.Some positives are that the game is visually pleasant, and most of the voice acting is well done.But ultimately I don't understand why this game has so many positive reviews, I just can't recommend that anyone buy it, there are so many other more worthy games to spend your time and money on.

content:
2
												So I briefly played this when it first launched on the 360 and never got more than 10 or so hours into it.  I decided to pick it back up and man was I plesantly suprised.  This is far from a perfect game but I've really enjoyed my time playing.  My biggest issue is just the combat system.  Its very clunky and just doesn't feel satisfying.  It's not unplayable, but it does hold the game back a bit.  What makes this game great is the writing.  I was constantly suprised by the dialogue both in the main quests and side quests.  Larian Studios are the kings of gaming comedy and if you have ever played the Original Sins series you will immediately recognize the humor.  Apart from the writing, being able to trasform into a dragon makes your character feel very powerful and cool.  There is a good bit of custimization you can do with your gear stat wise to make your character perform the way you want.  I would definately recommend picking this game up if you are looking for a fun RPG.  I probably wouldn't play through more than once but the game is fairly cheap now so I feel its well worth the money.

												A gentleman's game for gentlemen. Possibly the most criminally unapreciated game to come out in recent years.Soundtrack's still great, writing's still extraordinary, humor and self-awareness are still fully-intact, combat still ends with either you or the rude dudes dying within five seconds, and it still runs Gamebryo. Sorry about the last point, but it's still better than most of the things Bethesda's done with that engine in spite of having giant piles of money.So far as I can tell, the Developer's Cut adds some pretty neat design documents and artwork, along with a copy of aforementioned kickin' rad soundtrack and a mode that lets you mess around with the dev console. Not quite a full remaster (which would have been GOTY material) but a bit of extra gravy never hurt.

content:
, 2013
												I feel like this is an underappreciated gem.  It's something medieval RPG-lovers can really get into.  Swords!  Shields!  Armor!  Wenches!  Yippie!  Larian are some crazy awesome, Belgian developers.  To compare this to Skryim may be easy, but it's almost a disservice.  Divinity is unique and deserves to be viewed as a great title on its own.  It's everything I think Dark Souls should've been.  It's Skyrim, only you ARE the dragon.  Four-dimensional, fire-breathing air battles are in your future, my friend.  When you get sick of air combat, you can morph back to your human character and go questing.  This game is ridiculously awesome.  Made with the Gamebryo Engine, Bethesda fans will feel right at home (only without the bugs).  There's lots of dialog, consequence, loot, bartering, leveling your character, and did I mention you can morph into a m0t#3rfu({!n& dragon?!?  WHY DON'T YOU OWN THIS YET???

content:
8, 2015
												If you get this game, be sure to get the "developer's cut", as it contains the expansion, which you WILL want to play.Good combat - as an archer (which was my primary playthrough) you certainly can feel "overwhelmed" when facing hordes of nasty foes;  as you should.Storyline is good, voice acting is good.  Lots of humor hidden in there if you know where to look (and even if you don't)... Brave Sir Robin.  The quests and dungeons are fun to go through, and the puzzles.... can puzzle you.  There minimal (and at times none at all) as far as hand-holding goes for the quests and puzzles - which is a GOOD thing.  You won't be mindlessly following an arrow or looking for the magical sparkly button.  No.  You'll be in a dungeon, actually trying to figure out the puzzle, as it should be.  On rare occasions when you do get stuck, there's always walkthroughs...  Although racking your brain a little longer is much more rewarding when you finally DO figure it out.Also, there's no set classes.  You can play your character any way you want to (though I would suggest specializing in 3-5 skills).  It may not seem like much, but I'd much rather have a single poison arrrow that does nearly 400 damage over 20 seconds, than a bunch of arrows (stun, split arrow, fire arrow, pinning arrow, whatever) that does much less...  That is to say, it is true:  If you are a jack of all trades, you are a master of none.  And masters tend to pack a punch!Swing swords, shoot bows, blast 'em with fireballs, summon undead, summon demons, punch people with your bare fists...  fight however you want.   The only dis-advantage to this is... questing, story, and fighting is all there is to it.  No mini-games, no "romance", no craftng system so to speak...  But as an adventure story, it's top notch!Also?  You can play as a dragon.  (and own your own tower).It's true - you will be playing the game a while before you are a dragon.  The game is not rushed!  Many play-hours for you to enjoy, so enjoy it!I honestly wasn't expecting "that much" when I bought this game, and I was pleasantly surprised!  I would recommend this game to anybody who likes fantasy games - it caught me, that's for sure - hook line and sinker.  I can't wait to try the next game by these folks!

												You play as a dragon knight. That's all that needs to be said.Jokes aside, it's a rather well built game that if anything sometimes expects too much from the players. Don't expect to take less than 30 hours to complete it IF you skip all the sidequests. Actually, I don't know if you can even complete the game without completing all of the sidequests, because the difficulty curve is more like a difficulty LADDER, and if you're not strong enough to move up the big steps, you won't be getting anywhere anytime soon. Overall solid game, requires some dedication. It's not just "The dragon knight game", it's "The pretty challenging game where you can play a dragon knight if you're patient enough for it".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
9, 2015
												It's a thumbs up from me. Barely. Not a great game, but a decent one. The good outweighs the bad, but not by much. A flawed gem that should be purchased on sale (which given it's age now that's easy to do).THE GOOD? It's got loads of great humour in it for starters. Including lots of little side shows like rescuing a woman from undead, and then hearing her berate her husband later for sending someone out to rescue her and nagging at him about his marriage vows. Seriously plenty of funny moments. It's nice it doesn't take itself too seriously as a game.The other big plus is the quests are a little better than your average find this, go here, get this quests. There are lots of optional quests, you can ignore them (but you won't level enough if you do, so make sure you do a few). Fortunately many are interesting and entertaining enough to be reasonably worth the time. The skill system also is decent I guess - you can build any way you want. Just don't go shoving 1 point in everything - you'll suck.THE BAD? Well, there's a few issues. The first one is one of those annoyances that makes you want to punch stuff - whenever you are in a dialogue screen and then come out of it into combat, even if you had your weapons drawn, they are now sheathed. And it takes ages to pull them out. While you are fumbling aimlessly (even though you had them out before the chat), you are getting wailed on. In some fights that can matter. It's dumb. It's unnecessary, and bloody frustrating.RPG games are often made or broken on the use of quest logs, maping markers etc. This game falls WELL short in that dept. It's HARD remembering where you did something to get back there once you've got the thing you were after...  - you can't make a quest active with a marker to help you out, and unless you are truly anal, you won't bother with writing notes to help yourself. This bit really does suck. It makes the game frustrating at times. You run around trying to remember which place to go back to to close out parts of the story. Poor. Annoying. A bad oversight.Like I said at the start - it's ok. I've played worse RPGs. I've played better though - quite a few better ones...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
2, 2015
												(Summary)Pros: Fun quests, excellent combat, funny dialogue, wonderful sense of progression, lots of interesting ideas and innovations rarely seen in RPG's (like mind-reading at the cost of xp) and yet another excellent soundtrack by Kirill Pokrovsky, who is sadly no longer with us. Cons: Hasen't really aged well in terms of graphics and has some pretty stiff and awkward animations. Also, the main story is just okay, and won't really mean a whole lot to you if you aren't familiar with the series. Overall: 8/10(Lengthy bit where I ♥♥♥♥♥ about Ultima) The Divinity series is interesting. It's a series that clearly and openly takes cues from the old Ultima series; a series that has the distinction of having some of the best RPG's of all time AND some of the worst. If I were to describe the first Divinity game, Divine Divinity, in a nutshell, it would be "Ultima 8: Pagan, but good." Divinity 2 gets a similar description with regards to the disaster that was Ultima 9: Accension. It's a large, open world third person action RPG. The game will expect you to do a lot of exploration, talk to a lot of people, face some pretty damn challenging enemies and solve some pretty interesting puzles, like playing a game of riddles with a talking treasure box. The game also does something very well that Ultima 9 failed at miserably; making you feel powerful. In Ultima 9 your character was the Titan of Ether, a god in a sense, and both the story and the game itself didn't even seem to notice. At an early point in Divinity 2 your character becomes a Dragon Knight, which is a really big deal for the setting, and the changes that it inflicts upon your character over the course of the game are pretty substantial, and most importantly, they're actually FELT. Not just within the contet of the game, but the series as a whole. The distinction between your character in Divinity 2 and the other characters you play as over the course of the series, even taking engine differences and personal customization into account, is literally night and day, and it does an excellent job of making you feel like a budding top-tier entity in the world of Rivellon.

												I totally LOVE playing this and the other games in the Divinity Anthology.   This one is my favorite one for so many reasons.  This is total FUN!!!  Just the right amount of mob grinds and interesting and interactive questing.  I never hungered for either nor opportunities to advanced my character. content:
er 19, 2015
												I'll start by saying that I don't know a damn thing about this series. I got it just because I thought it looked cool. That being said, I wasn't entirely sure what to expect other than, well, an RPG.The atmosphere is okay. The music is great. I liked the art style, but the actual implementation of the environmental textures and models feels a bit sloppily done, like an MMO. For example, in Aleroth City, the paved areas extend well beyond the buildings and climb up the terrain; Pavers look pretty stupid when they're painted all over the hills. I'm fairly certain these areas were intended to be hidden from view, but often can be seen by just rotating the camera.The scale of the game is quite impressive, excellent for facilitating the dragon mechanics. The transition between the human and dragon forms is pretty smooth, but considering the enemies for each of these forms will only attack, and only be able to be attacked, when the player is in the proper form, it sometimes seems a bit pointless to restrict the ability to transform.The quests are pretty fun. There's a good mix of variety and routine. They don't really lead the player around too much, but the difficulty of the enemies in the main story quests often make it difficult to progress without sucking all of the experience possible out of the side quests.The combat also feels a bit weird. The majority of the difficulty comes from having to face multiple opponents at once. The game provides several options to even the odds, in the form of summons, necromancy, and charm spells, but the primary purpose of these always seems to be giving the enemies more targets, rather than providing oneself with a direct offensive output. Even tank builds feel very limited in their damage output. No matter what weapons the player has, everything is DPS, and when the enemy starts cranking out overpowered healing spells, fights drag out longer. It's all a matter of whether the player can mash the attack button until the enemy dies. There is very little real strategy.Overall, it's okay. It's not perfect, but provides a decent amount of immersive gameplay for your buck.

content:
y 1
												I played this game first time in 2011-2012 and I replayed it in 2017.What can I tell you about this game? I love it!The RPGs from Larian Studio are always have some unique features and interesting characters.In this game:1.	You can explore a vast open world. It is not as big as worlds from Bethesda (like Skyrim / Fallout) but it is pretty big. There are many places to go and things to see.2.	You can read other people minds. Sometimes it can be fun, sometimes it can provide you with some lore about world, experience points or skill points.3.	You have your own undead pet – a pretty useful companion. You can find different body parts for your pet and customize it with the help of a necromancer.4.	You have your own Battle tower with several subordinates who can help you with necromancy, blacksmithing or alchemy.5.	You have plenty skills for use – from conjuring spirits to rush attacks with your swords.6.	You will find dozens (if not hundreds) of puzzles and secrets. Even in the training area a sharp-sighted player can find something interesting! And most of the times the game will not give you any direct hints (like flags on the map), so you actually need to carefully read texts and look for hints. Do yourself a favor – don’t use any online guides unless you completely stuck.7.	You can transform into a dragon!8.	There are dozens and dozens of quests, especially in the second part.9.	There are plenty interesting NPC, I bet you won’t forget Bellegar )10.	And many other things …Of course, it is not an ideal game.There are some flaws in combat system and using the dragon form can be boring sometimes, but all these little things weren’t able to spoil my fun.As I said before – I love this game. It is very distinctive from other RPGs and for me it is one of the most important feature in games.

content:
2, 2015
												(Summary)Pros: Fun quests, excellent combat, funny dialogue, wonderful sense of progression, lots of interesting ideas and innovations rarely seen in RPG's (like mind-reading at the cost of xp) and yet another excellent soundtrack by Kirill Pokrovsky, who is sadly no longer with us. Cons: Hasen't really aged well in terms of graphics and has some pretty stiff and awkward animations. Also, the main story is just okay, and won't really mean a whole lot to you if you aren't familiar with the series. Overall: 8/10(Lengthy bit where I ♥♥♥♥♥ about Ultima) The Divinity series is interesting. It's a series that clearly and openly takes cues from the old Ultima series; a series that has the distinction of having some of the best RPG's of all time AND some of the worst. If I were to describe the first Divinity game, Divine Divinity, in a nutshell, it would be "Ultima 8: Pagan, but good." Divinity 2 gets a similar description with regards to the disaster that was Ultima 9: Accension. It's a large, open world third person action RPG. The game will expect you to do a lot of exploration, talk to a lot of people, face some pretty damn challenging enemies and solve some pretty interesting puzles, like playing a game of riddles with a talking treasure box. The game also does something very well that Ultima 9 failed at miserably; making you feel powerful. In Ultima 9 your character was the Titan of Ether, a god in a sense, and both the story and the game itself didn't even seem to notice. At an early point in Divinity 2 your character becomes a Dragon Knight, which is a really big deal for the setting, and the changes that it inflicts upon your character over the course of the game are pretty substantial, and most importantly, they're actually FELT. Not just within the contet of the game, but the series as a whole. The distinction between your character in Divinity 2 and the other characters you play as over the course of the series, even taking engine differences and personal customization into account, is literally night and day, and it does an excellent job of making you feel like a budding top-tier entity in the world of Rivellon.

content:
2, 2015
												Divinity II: Developer's Cut is a highly under appreciated game that does not receive the attention it deserves. This is basically the Collector's Edition of the Game of the Year version of the original game. Simply put, the original game was very buggy and re-released with DLC, a new game engine, and many bug fixes. This improves on that re-release.To compare it to more well known games, it features combat similar to the Elder Scrolls series, loot and upgrades similar to Diablo series, and (less influential) dialogue chooses from the Mass Effect Series. There is also a tremendous skill tree from which you can mix and match all play styles without restriction (other than your level). Two unique features in the game are mind reading, which usually allows you to find additional loot, and turning into a dragon, which has very smooth controls but less expansive combat.The story is kind of all over the place, but it needs to be mentioned that the ending of the main game is terrible. I will not spoil it, but the game ends without any kind of big moment. There are, however, some twists and a tone that isn'y present in many games. The included DLC is great in terms of flushing out an entire city with numerous type of unique people, personalities, and quests. However, once again the main story is not consistent with the ending again feeling pretty cheap.Overall, Divinity II: Developer's Cut is a really good game. There are some bugs with it (I really only experienced 1 bug that didn't let me finish a side quest, but it was corrected in Developer's Mode). It may not blow you away, but it is still a very fun experience that allows a large amount of freedom. The game is a must buy on sale, but still worth the full price if not on sale.I posted an entire playthrough on my YouTube channel for anyone interest in checking out aspects of gameplay.  Base game  and  DLC

content:
9, 2015
												It's a thumbs up from me. Barely. Not a great game, but a decent one. The good outweighs the bad, but not by much. A flawed gem that should be purchased on sale (which given it's age now that's easy to do).THE GOOD? It's got loads of great humour in it for starters. Including lots of little side shows like rescuing a woman from undead, and then hearing her berate her husband later for sending someone out to rescue her and nagging at him about his marriage vows. Seriously plenty of funny moments. It's nice it doesn't take itself too seriously as a game.The other big plus is the quests are a little better than your average find this, go here, get this quests. There are lots of optional quests, you can ignore them (but you won't level enough if you do, so make sure you do a few). Fortunately many are interesting and entertaining enough to be reasonably worth the time. The skill system also is decent I guess - you can build any way you want. Just don't go shoving 1 point in everything - you'll suck.THE BAD? Well, there's a few issues. The first one is one of those annoyances that makes you want to punch stuff - whenever you are in a dialogue screen and then come out of it into combat, even if you had your weapons drawn, they are now sheathed. And it takes ages to pull them out. While you are fumbling aimlessly (even though you had them out before the chat), you are getting wailed on. In some fights that can matter. It's dumb. It's unnecessary, and bloody frustrating.RPG games are often made or broken on the use of quest logs, maping markers etc. This game falls WELL short in that dept. It's HARD remembering where you did something to get back there once you've got the thing you were after...  - you can't make a quest active with a marker to help you out, and unless you are truly anal, you won't bother with writing notes to help yourself. This bit really does suck. It makes the game frustrating at times. You run around trying to remember which place to go back to to close out parts of the story. Poor. Annoying. A bad oversight.Like I said at the start - it's ok. I've played worse RPGs. I've played better though - quite a few better ones...

												Divinity is an adventure RPG where you, the gamer are put into a world of mystical creatures and are a "Dragon Slayer". If you've played the first Divinity and bought the 2nd game before this version, then you'll most likely know the story. Since this is the "Developer's Cut" there is plenty of added content to this game, such as new transformations, weapons and so much more. The game is wonderfully atmospheric, and is also unique. You'd think this would be like a Skyrim clone, but it's not. I won't give anything away, because the story is worth it. However, it allows you to design your character, but what brings it down is that you're limited to how you can make it, VERY limited. And sometimes, if you're PC doesn't work properly, the game can freeze or shut down. So be mindful. Otherwise, this game is fantastic, and I'd play this game any day (Even though I don't play it cause I'm not on all the time XD)

y 5, 2014
												An RPG where you play as a character that can turn into a giant dragon, take to the sky and rain fire on enemies! Has very good character development mechanics for an RPG and offering a very flexible skill tree system where you can pick skills and upgrades from any branch (example: make a warrior with a fireball spell from the sorcery branch). The game is open world and has a strong storyline to encourage gamers to continue developing their characters and find out what will happen next. I haven't played either of the earlier games, but I think this game is set 1000 years after them and I think the NPCs refer to the events of the previous games as well as the hero characters from said games.Only bad thing I can say about this game is it is a difficult game, even on normal difficulty. The game gives you very steep difficulty curves and (because I picked to make a Warrior class) the Warrior class has a very hard time because many of the enemies are ranged with poison spells and this makes me have to resort to using a bow which is supposed to be for a thief or ranger class in my opinion. I would advise making a ranged character if you dislike challenges.PS: You can choose to play the original version of the game instead of the director's cut.

content:
8, 2015
												If you get this game, be sure to get the "developer's cut", as it contains the expansion, which you WILL want to play.Good combat - as an archer (which was my primary playthrough) you certainly can feel "overwhelmed" when facing hordes of nasty foes;  as you should.Storyline is good, voice acting is good.  Lots of humor hidden in there if you know where to look (and even if you don't)... Brave Sir Robin.  The quests and dungeons are fun to go through, and the puzzles.... can puzzle you.  There minimal (and at times none at all) as far as hand-holding goes for the quests and puzzles - which is a GOOD thing.  You won't be mindlessly following an arrow or looking for the magical sparkly button.  No.  You'll be in a dungeon, actually trying to figure out the puzzle, as it should be.  On rare occasions when you do get stuck, there's always walkthroughs...  Although racking your brain a little longer is much more rewarding when you finally DO figure it out.Also, there's no set classes.  You can play your character any way you want to (though I would suggest specializing in 3-5 skills).  It may not seem like much, but I'd much rather have a single poison arrrow that does nearly 400 damage over 20 seconds, than a bunch of arrows (stun, split arrow, fire arrow, pinning arrow, whatever) that does much less...  That is to say, it is true:  If you are a jack of all trades, you are a master of none.  And masters tend to pack a punch!Swing swords, shoot bows, blast 'em with fireballs, summon undead, summon demons, punch people with your bare fists...  fight however you want.   The only dis-advantage to this is... questing, story, and fighting is all there is to it.  No mini-games, no "romance", no craftng system so to speak...  But as an adventure story, it's top notch!Also?  You can play as a dragon.  (and own your own tower).It's true - you will be playing the game a while before you are a dragon.  The game is not rushed!  Many play-hours for you to enjoy, so enjoy it!I honestly wasn't expecting "that much" when I bought this game, and I was pleasantly surprised!  I would recommend this game to anybody who likes fantasy games - it caught me, that's for sure - hook line and sinker.  I can't wait to try the next game by these folks!

												You play as a dragon knight. That's all that needs to be said.Jokes aside, it's a rather well built game that if anything sometimes expects too much from the players. Don't expect to take less than 30 hours to complete it IF you skip all the sidequests. Actually, I don't know if you can even complete the game without completing all of the sidequests, because the difficulty curve is more like a difficulty LADDER, and if you're not strong enough to move up the big steps, you won't be getting anywhere anytime soon. Overall solid game, requires some dedication. It's not just "The dragon knight game", it's "The pretty challenging game where you can play a dragon knight if you're patient enough for it".

												This will be my first game I've ever review on steam, and for a good reason. This game is a gem. Its a little rough round the edges, but a gem nonetheless. Multiple ending side quests, an engaging combat system, some great script writing, and consistantly good voice acting, these features really stand out after having played so much skyrim and oblivion. Moreover, the universe manages to avoid feeling generic, something that cannot be said for many other RPGs, cough Kingdoms of Amalur, cough. The lack of hand holding removes quest tedium, forcing the player to pay attentions to what is going on. The stand out problems so far, a few jerky animations, a little grindy to unlock new skills, a lack of character customisation. Lets be fair though, its a 2009 game. Anyone interested in RPGS should take a look.

er 4, 2012
												I have tried again and again to play, and like, this game - but I really just can't. The skills and stats are kinda wonky at best, but first the good stuff: It is largely voiced, it looks decent, there's a pretty decent story. But the combat is just wonky as all hell. It's awkward and unpleasant, things have tons of health, your skills have long cooldowns, cost lots of mana and are largely not very powerful or worthwhile. You can't block, and moving is too lagged by attacking that you will be hit constantly unless you roll around from side to side endlessly, and even then it's unresponsive. I feel it coulda been good, but the combat's awkwardness makes it nearly unbearable.

												A solid RPG. I played the entire game -- 67 hours (the Director's Cut includes both the original and the expansion pack, Flames of Vengeance.) I liked the streamlined skill tree -- it made it easy to try new skills. Plus, you don't have to pick a class. I used explosive arrows from the Ranger tree, and a couple skills from the Meele tree (whilrwind, thousand strikes) -- when I wasn't tossing fireballs.The early game is pretty basic, but after awhile, you get to become a dragon, and that made the game uniquely fun (the dragon never felt as powerful as my human form, however, which seems really counter-intuitive. You also can't wipe out humans on the ground with your flame breath -- that would no doubt be too easy.)My biggest issue was the vague quest system. There are no markers for the subsequent steps in quests, and what exactly you need to do is not spelled out. A lot of the quests left me scratching my head, wondering where the game wanted me to go next. I have limited play time, and while I like to explore, I don't really enjoy retracing the same steps over and over as I run around the countryside or in town, trying to remember where Bernard or Benedict or Brutus was when I picked up his quest days earlier.  Keeping track of 20+ quests and each one's next steps required more devotion to detail than I was willing to spend. If you find that to be the case, you might do what I did, and print out quest guides from Game Banshee or the various Divinity wikis (or have them in a browser and Alt+TAB, of course). I'm a completist, and didn't want to miss any side quests. BTW, I played Divinity: Original Sin before this one, and that game's questing system was perfect!My only other complaint was it takes far too long to get your home base -- so managing your inventory is a real pain, unless you spend skill points to be able to lug more stuff, or sell off stuff you're not even sure you need yet.Other than that , I had a good time and would recommend the game to anyone who likes fantasy RPGs.

												An RPG where you play as a character that can turn into a giant dragon, take to the sky and rain fire on enemies! Has very good character development mechanics for an RPG and offering a very flexible skill tree system where you can pick skills and upgrades from any branch (example: make a warrior with a fireball spell from the sorcery branch). The game is open world and has a strong storyline to encourage gamers to continue developing their characters and find out what will happen next. I haven't played either of the earlier games, but I think this game is set 1000 years after them and I think the NPCs refer to the events of the previous games as well as the hero characters from said games.Only bad thing I can say about this game is it is a difficult game, even on normal difficulty. The game gives you very steep difficulty curves and (because I picked to make a Warrior class) the Warrior class has a very hard time because many of the enemies are ranged with poison spells and this makes me have to resort to using a bow which is supposed to be for a thief or ranger class in my opinion. I would advise making a ranged character if you dislike challenges.PS: You can choose to play the original version of the game instead of the director's cut.

content:
er 19, 2015
												I'll start by saying that I don't know a damn thing about this series. I got it just because I thought it looked cool. That being said, I wasn't entirely sure what to expect other than, well, an RPG.The atmosphere is okay. The music is great. I liked the art style, but the actual implementation of the environmental textures and models feels a bit sloppily done, like an MMO. For example, in Aleroth City, the paved areas extend well beyond the buildings and climb up the terrain; Pavers look pretty stupid when they're painted all over the hills. I'm fairly certain these areas were intended to be hidden from view, but often can be seen by just rotating the camera.The scale of the game is quite impressive, excellent for facilitating the dragon mechanics. The transition between the human and dragon forms is pretty smooth, but considering the enemies for each of these forms will only attack, and only be able to be attacked, when the player is in the proper form, it sometimes seems a bit pointless to restrict the ability to transform.The quests are pretty fun. There's a good mix of variety and routine. They don't really lead the player around too much, but the difficulty of the enemies in the main story quests often make it difficult to progress without sucking all of the experience possible out of the side quests.The combat also feels a bit weird. The majority of the difficulty comes from having to face multiple opponents at once. The game provides several options to even the odds, in the form of summons, necromancy, and charm spells, but the primary purpose of these always seems to be giving the enemies more targets, rather than providing oneself with a direct offensive output. Even tank builds feel very limited in their damage output. No matter what weapons the player has, everything is DPS, and when the enemy starts cranking out overpowered healing spells, fights drag out longer. It's all a matter of whether the player can mash the attack button until the enemy dies. There is very little real strategy.Overall, it's okay. It's not perfect, but provides a decent amount of immersive gameplay for your buck.

No way.Now, Steam sells the Developer's Cut for 4€ and I ask myself, why did I ever even buy any game at a store?I could already recommend Ego Draconis for what it was, even with the unsatisfactory ending. But after finishing FoV, I go from saying 'it's worth a try' to 'an action rpg you HAVE to try!'

content:
2, 2015
												Divinity II: Developer's Cut is a highly under appreciated game that does not receive the attention it deserves. This is basically the Collector's Edition of the Game of the Year version of the original game. Simply put, the original game was very buggy and re-released with DLC, a new game engine, and many bug fixes. This improves on that re-release.To compare it to more well known games, it features combat similar to the Elder Scrolls series, loot and upgrades similar to Diablo series, and (less influential) dialogue chooses from the Mass Effect Series. There is also a tremendous skill tree from which you can mix and match all play styles without restriction (other than your level). Two unique features in the game are mind reading, which usually allows you to find additional loot, and turning into a dragon, which has very smooth controls but less expansive combat.The story is kind of all over the place, but it needs to be mentioned that the ending of the main game is terrible. I will not spoil it, but the game ends without any kind of big moment. There are, however, some twists and a tone that isn'y present in many games. The included DLC is great in terms of flushing out an entire city with numerous type of unique people, personalities, and quests. However, once again the main story is not consistent with the ending again feeling pretty cheap.Overall, Divinity II: Developer's Cut is a really good game. There are some bugs with it (I really only experienced 1 bug that didn't let me finish a side quest, but it was corrected in Developer's Mode). It may not blow you away, but it is still a very fun experience that allows a large amount of freedom. The game is a must buy on sale, but still worth the full price if not on sale.I posted an entire playthrough on my YouTube channel for anyone interest in checking out aspects of gameplay.  Base game  and  DLC

content:
2, 2015
												(Summary)Pros: Fun quests, excellent combat, funny dialogue, wonderful sense of progression, lots of interesting ideas and innovations rarely seen in RPG's (like mind-reading at the cost of xp) and yet another excellent soundtrack by Kirill Pokrovsky, who is sadly no longer with us. Cons: Hasen't really aged well in terms of graphics and has some pretty stiff and awkward animations. Also, the main story is just okay, and won't really mean a whole lot to you if you aren't familiar with the series. Overall: 8/10(Lengthy bit where I ♥♥♥♥♥ about Ultima) The Divinity series is interesting. It's a series that clearly and openly takes cues from the old Ultima series; a series that has the distinction of having some of the best RPG's of all time AND some of the worst. If I were to describe the first Divinity game, Divine Divinity, in a nutshell, it would be "Ultima 8: Pagan, but good." Divinity 2 gets a similar description with regards to the disaster that was Ultima 9: Accension. It's a large, open world third person action RPG. The game will expect you to do a lot of exploration, talk to a lot of people, face some pretty damn challenging enemies and solve some pretty interesting puzles, like playing a game of riddles with a talking treasure box. The game also does something very well that Ultima 9 failed at miserably; making you feel powerful. In Ultima 9 your character was the Titan of Ether, a god in a sense, and both the story and the game itself didn't even seem to notice. At an early point in Divinity 2 your character becomes a Dragon Knight, which is a really big deal for the setting, and the changes that it inflicts upon your character over the course of the game are pretty substantial, and most importantly, they're actually FELT. Not just within the contet of the game, but the series as a whole. The distinction between your character in Divinity 2 and the other characters you play as over the course of the series, even taking engine differences and personal customization into account, is literally night and day, and it does an excellent job of making you feel like a budding top-tier entity in the world of Rivellon.

2015
												This review contains SPOILERS.Please bear in mind, the following is my opinion alone. You may disagree with my opinion.This review is for Part One, Ego Draconis.Divinity II: Developer's Cut is a brilliant game, possibly (with the exception of Skyrim) the best.Firstly, you have all the classic RPG elements - goblins, evil necromancers, legends and prophecies and stuff, and of course female armour which seems to protect you more the less of it there is. That makes perfect sense, right...?There's a plot twist early on in the game in which you become a Dragon Knight - a Dragon Slayer blessed with increased power who can turn into a dragon by using the Dragon Stone.A fecking DRAGON. That fact alone makes the game amazing.You select a class at the beginning, but you can eventually sort of make your own as the game progresses - you're not entirely stuck into one class like Mage or Necromancer or Warrior or Archer, you can morph them into something new. I call mine a Battle Mage - A Mage/Necromancer who has some Warrior skills.Of course, as with every game, there are cons. The level design for Sentinel Island is simply appalling - it takes twenty million years to get anywhere and once you get there you have to engage in a short conversation and then travel for another twenty million years to go and have another short conversation and then you travel for another twenty million years to get to the bloody totem to choose the person you want for a specific role.You have to do that four times.The switching between Dragon and Human could also be a bit smoother, and so could the movement when you are a Dragon.There's also the problem with the female armour.RATINGSGraphics - 6/10Gameplay - 8/10Story Originality - 3/10The Actual Story - 6/10Value for Money - 5/10 - Should be more like £10.99 not £12.99Replayability - 5/10 - You can re-play the game with different classes but eventually it will get boringLength - 6/10 - I haven't yet finished my current game and I have spent about 6 hours on itExtra Special Feature - You can become a dragon. Need I say more?My Final Rating:8.5/10Very Good/Excellent

content:
6, 2015
												A very overlooked game, due to problems and a messy release (thanks to the publisher). It also couldn´t hide its obviously intention for a console release, which lead to clunky controls and the typical "port" feeling on the pc (despite the game being released on pc first). However, Larian is a great Dev-studio and seems very dedicated to iron out its mistakes and thanks to the Directors Cut we get a very good open-ish RPG experience.*Graphics and Sound*They still look very pretty and while it can´t keep up with time, the art style and overall love for detail creates an environment that holds up, combine this with the fantastic soundtrack and immersion is given in this game. Sometimes bad textures stick out and not much variation in animation, however the game is several years old and its nothing to really sniff at. The soundtrack is really fantastic, i would go so far as saying that it is one of Larians biggest strength in all of their games. Keep the sound up and you won´t be disappointed. The atmosphere created is spot on!*Technical side*I have not seen one bug, whatsover. I also had zero crashes on Win7 64x. Obviously thats just my experience and others my vary.*Gameplay*I´m pretty sure controler wouldn´t be in issue, this of course can be helped with free 3th pary software, however i choose keyboard+mouse and it worked fine. The combat is action-hotkey oriented, however movement makes a difference (like jumping and then smashing down on enemies). Most of the enemy fire can also be dodged. Still, it does become a bit repetitive after some time, this might be because i choose a melee character to play, but it certainly has also to do with the very odd power curve in the game. While at the beginning one could sometimes struggle in fights and go thru some health potions, you later become a monster and just hack thru enemies. The game also rewards exploration and riddle solving giving you (in my opinion) sometimes overpowerd items as a reward, this making you to powerful early on. Neverless, combat is sufficiently and the dragon form mixes it up enough. Riddles and hidden treasure were a big surprise, sometimes very hard to catch/see and some required actual thinking. Thats rare. Respecing is always possible when the player gets his strongehold. There is also crafting in the game, which except from enchanting, i never needed though. An important thing i need to mention that others pointed out wrongly. Yes it is openworld-ish, but more in the theme of Baldurs Gate (actualy less): you get your main story and you can explore the current zone(s). But not progress further until you finished your main quest in these. So its not like Skyrim and the world is also not that big. Also it is true that you can´t import your save from the first one...but i think there is an autosave generated because the directors cut treats the game as a whole with the expansion AND you have your gear/money and everything still when you enter the x-pac section of the game.*Story*Story is important in a RPG and Divinity 2 does deliver but also lacks depth. The story isn´t bad and there are some twists and turns, especially at the end. Any RPG player however won´t find a lot of surprises, its pretty generic. However, the big strength in Larian games are the side quests, filled with hints, riddles, very funny dialouge and options. They are the main drive force of the game, and to me, are the interesting part. There are also enough of them to keep you playing. *Overall opinion*For 20.- its definitely worth the purchase, even better with a deal. Its a good RPG that rewards exploration and thinking, with a not so great combat system but lots of humor and interesting quests in it. Overall i think the ambition behind it was just bigger than the budget (this reminded me a LOT of Kingdoms of Amalur). Still, i expected much less and was really surprised.

content:
8, 2015
												If you get this game, be sure to get the "developer's cut", as it contains the expansion, which you WILL want to play.Good combat - as an archer (which was my primary playthrough) you certainly can feel "overwhelmed" when facing hordes of nasty foes;  as you should.Storyline is good, voice acting is good.  Lots of humor hidden in there if you know where to look (and even if you don't)... Brave Sir Robin.  The quests and dungeons are fun to go through, and the puzzles.... can puzzle you.  There minimal (and at times none at all) as far as hand-holding goes for the quests and puzzles - which is a GOOD thing.  You won't be mindlessly following an arrow or looking for the magical sparkly button.  No.  You'll be in a dungeon, actually trying to figure out the puzzle, as it should be.  On rare occasions when you do get stuck, there's always walkthroughs...  Although racking your brain a little longer is much more rewarding when you finally DO figure it out.Also, there's no set classes.  You can play your character any way you want to (though I would suggest specializing in 3-5 skills).  It may not seem like much, but I'd much rather have a single poison arrrow that does nearly 400 damage over 20 seconds, than a bunch of arrows (stun, split arrow, fire arrow, pinning arrow, whatever) that does much less...  That is to say, it is true:  If you are a jack of all trades, you are a master of none.  And masters tend to pack a punch!Swing swords, shoot bows, blast 'em with fireballs, summon undead, summon demons, punch people with your bare fists...  fight however you want.   The only dis-advantage to this is... questing, story, and fighting is all there is to it.  No mini-games, no "romance", no craftng system so to speak...  But as an adventure story, it's top notch!Also?  You can play as a dragon.  (and own your own tower).It's true - you will be playing the game a while before you are a dragon.  The game is not rushed!  Many play-hours for you to enjoy, so enjoy it!I honestly wasn't expecting "that much" when I bought this game, and I was pleasantly surprised!  I would recommend this game to anybody who likes fantasy games - it caught me, that's for sure - hook line and sinker.  I can't wait to try the next game by these folks!

The level design for Sentinel Island is simply appalling - it takes twenty million years to get anywhere and once you get there you have to engage in a short conversation and then travel for another twenty million years to go and have another short conversation and then you travel for another twenty million years to get to the bloody totem to choose the person you want for a specific role.You have to do that four times.The switching between Dragon and Human could also be a bit smoother, and so could the movement when you are a Dragon.There's also the problem with the female armour.RATINGSGraphics - 6/10Gameplay - 8/10Story Originality - 3/10The Actual Story - 6/10Value for Money - 5/10 - Should be more like £10.99 not £12.99Replayability - 5/10 - You can re-play the game with different classes but eventually it will get boringLength - 6/10 - I haven't yet finished my current game and I have spent about 6 hours on itExtra Special Feature - You can become a dragon. Need I say more?My Final Rating:8.5/10Very Good/Excellent

content:
2015
												A solid RPG. I played the entire game -- 67 hours (the Director's Cut includes both the original and the expansion pack, Flames of Vengeance.) I liked the streamlined skill tree -- it made it easy to try new skills. Plus, you don't have to pick a class. I used explosive arrows from the Ranger tree, and a couple skills from the Meele tree (whilrwind, thousand strikes) -- when I wasn't tossing fireballs.The early game is pretty basic, but after awhile, you get to become a dragon, and that made the game uniquely fun (the dragon never felt as powerful as my human form, however, which seems really counter-intuitive. You also can't wipe out humans on the ground with your flame breath -- that would no doubt be too easy.)My biggest issue was the vague quest system. There are no markers for the subsequent steps in quests, and what exactly you need to do is not spelled out. A lot of the quests left me scratching my head, wondering where the game wanted me to go next. I have limited play time, and while I like to explore, I don't really enjoy retracing the same steps over and over as I run around the countryside or in town, trying to remember where Bernard or Benedict or Brutus was when I picked up his quest days earlier.  Keeping track of 20+ quests and each one's next steps required more devotion to detail than I was willing to spend. If you find that to be the case, you might do what I did, and print out quest guides from Game Banshee or the various Divinity wikis (or have them in a browser and Alt+TAB, of course). I'm a completist, and didn't want to miss any side quests. BTW, I played Divinity: Original Sin before this one, and that game's questing system was perfect!My only other complaint was it takes far too long to get your home base -- so managing your inventory is a real pain, unless you spend skill points to be able to lug more stuff, or sell off stuff you're not even sure you need yet.Other than that , I had a good time and would recommend the game to anyone who likes fantasy RPGs.

												Divinity is an adventure RPG where you, the gamer are put into a world of mystical creatures and are a "Dragon Slayer". If you've played the first Divinity and bought the 2nd game before this version, then you'll most likely know the story. Since this is the "Developer's Cut" there is plenty of added content to this game, such as new transformations, weapons and so much more. The game is wonderfully atmospheric, and is also unique. You'd think this would be like a Skyrim clone, but it's not. I won't give anything away, because the story is worth it. However, it allows you to design your character, but what brings it down is that you're limited to how you can make it, VERY limited. And sometimes, if you're PC doesn't work properly, the game can freeze or shut down. So be mindful. Otherwise, this game is fantastic, and I'd play this game any day (Even though I don't play it cause I'm not on all the time XD)

content:
6, 2015
												A very overlooked game, due to problems and a messy release (thanks to the publisher). It also couldn´t hide its obviously intention for a console release, which lead to clunky controls and the typical "port" feeling on the pc (despite the game being released on pc first). However, Larian is a great Dev-studio and seems very dedicated to iron out its mistakes and thanks to the Directors Cut we get a very good open-ish RPG experience.*Graphics and Sound*They still look very pretty and while it can´t keep up with time, the art style and overall love for detail creates an environment that holds up, combine this with the fantastic soundtrack and immersion is given in this game. Sometimes bad textures stick out and not much variation in animation, however the game is several years old and its nothing to really sniff at. The soundtrack is really fantastic, i would go so far as saying that it is one of Larians biggest strength in all of their games. Keep the sound up and you won´t be disappointed. The atmosphere created is spot on!*Technical side*I have not seen one bug, whatsover. I also had zero crashes on Win7 64x. Obviously thats just my experience and others my vary.*Gameplay*I´m pretty sure controler wouldn´t be in issue, this of course can be helped with free 3th pary software, however i choose keyboard+mouse and it worked fine. The combat is action-hotkey oriented, however movement makes a difference (like jumping and then smashing down on enemies). Most of the enemy fire can also be dodged. Still, it does become a bit repetitive after some time, this might be because i choose a melee character to play, but it certainly has also to do with the very odd power curve in the game. While at the beginning one could sometimes struggle in fights and go thru some health potions, you later become a monster and just hack thru enemies. The game also rewards exploration and riddle solving giving you (in my opinion) sometimes overpowerd items as a reward, this making you to powerful early on. Neverless, combat is sufficiently and the dragon form mixes it up enough. Riddles and hidden treasure were a big surprise, sometimes very hard to catch/see and some required actual thinking. Thats rare. Respecing is always possible when the player gets his strongehold. There is also crafting in the game, which except from enchanting, i never needed though. An important thing i need to mention that others pointed out wrongly. Yes it is openworld-ish, but more in the theme of Baldurs Gate (actualy less): you get your main story and you can explore the current zone(s). But not progress further until you finished your main quest in these. So its not like Skyrim and the world is also not that big. Also it is true that you can´t import your save from the first one...but i think there is an autosave generated because the directors cut treats the game as a whole with the expansion AND you have your gear/money and everything still when you enter the x-pac section of the game.*Story*Story is important in a RPG and Divinity 2 does deliver but also lacks depth. The story isn´t bad and there are some twists and turns, especially at the end. Any RPG player however won´t find a lot of surprises, its pretty generic. However, the big strength in Larian games are the side quests, filled with hints, riddles, very funny dialouge and options. They are the main drive force of the game, and to me, are the interesting part. There are also enough of them to keep you playing. *Overall opinion*For 20.- its definitely worth the purchase, even better with a deal. Its a good RPG that rewards exploration and thinking, with a not so great combat system but lots of humor and interesting quests in it. Overall i think the ambition behind it was just bigger than the budget (this reminded me a LOT of Kingdoms of Amalur). Still, i expected much less and was really surprised.

												Note: that I have no hours because I found it on sale elsewhere and refunded on steam. This is a 50h game plus 20h expansion. This game is huge with tons of skills which you are totally free to take at any time. So you can make your character do basically anything. The combat is good, same with the visuals and music. I especially like the music. The story is also above average for sure and being a dragon is pretty sick.The drawbacks are all in the level design. Often they will trap you in a room and you must just search for the tiny book (in an entire ♥♥♥♥ing library) or key to click on in an entire area of interactables. Often these interactables will chunk you for 55% of your max hp if you pick the wrong thing. This leads to just reloading and searching for WAY too long in many places. So I strongly recommend just googling every time you are stuck so you can focus on the great parts of the game which is combat, story, exploring, and your characters development. It even has some platforming elements which are fun too.Plus there is no fall damage so you can skydive off of towers. Later in the game you can skydive, then halfway through your fall, turn into a dragon and fly away. But in the best interests for your sanity, google through the "puzzles" which are basically click on stuff which kills you until you find the hidden thing to click on which doesn't
